abydus: <entryFree id="n279" type="main" key="A^by_dus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăbȳdus</orth> and <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăbȳdos</orth>, <itype>i</itype> (in MSS. also <orth extent="full" lang="la">Aboedus</orth>), <gen>f.</gen> (<gen>m.</gen>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:207" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 207</bibl>), = <foreign lang="greek">*a)/budos</foreign>, <sense id="n279.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town in Mysia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on the narrowest point of the Hellespont</hi>, <hi rend="ital">opposite Sestos</hi>, now perh. <hi rend="ital">Aidos</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Avido</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:1:9:1" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 1, 9, 1</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 4, 54, 68</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ostrifer,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:207" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 207</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mea,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:18:127" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 18, 127</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">19, 30 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Abydum oppidum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:141" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 32, 40, § 141</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n279.1" n="II" level="1"> Hence deriv.: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăbȳdēnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">belonging to Abydus</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">juvenis, i. e. Leander,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:1:2:87" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 1, 2, 87</bibl></cit>; the same <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Abydenus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:18:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 18, 1</bibl></cit>.—In <number>plur.</number>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăbȳdēni</orth>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of Abydus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:31:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 31, 16</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
abyla: <entryFree id="n280" type="main" key="A^by^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăbyla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)abu/lh</foreign>, <sense id="n280.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a spur of a mountain in Africa</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on the strait of Gibraltar</hi>, one of the Pillars of Hercules, opposite Calpe, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:15:3" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 15, 3</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Avien.</author> Perieg. 111</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
abyssus: <entryFree id="n281" type="greek" key="a^byssus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăbyssus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/bussos</foreign> (sc. <foreign lang="greek">li/mnh</foreign>). <sense id="n281.0" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">A bottomless pit</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an abyss</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 13, 20</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n281.1" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">The sea</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,001:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Gen. 1, 2</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n281.2" n="3" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">The place of the dead</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Orcus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Hades</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,006:10:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Rom. 10, 7</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n281.3" n="4" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">Tartarus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hell</hi>, where the wicked are confined, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,003:8:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Luc. 8, 31</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,027:9:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Apoc. 9, 1</bibl>. So in eccl. Lat.</sense></entryFree>
ac: <entryFree id="n282" type="main" key="AC1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">AC</orth>, <itype>a Latin root, denoting</itype> (<sense id="n282.0" n="1" level="3">) <hi rend="ital">sharp</hi> and (</sense><sense id="n282.1" n="2" level="3">) <hi rend="ital">quick</hi>, kindred with the Greek <foreign lang="greek">a)/kros</foreign> and <foreign lang="greek">w)k-u/s</foreign>, Sanscr. ācu (= celeriter). Hence the Latin acer, acies, acuo, acus, acutus, aquila, accipiter, acupedius (prob. also equus), ocior, and oculus.</sense></entryFree>
<entryFree id="n283" type="main" key="ac2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac</orth>, <sense id="n283.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">conj.</hi>, v. atque.</sense></entryFree>
acacia: <entryFree id="n284" type="greek" key="a^ca_ci^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcācĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)kaki/a</foreign>. <sense id="n284.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The acacia-tree</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the Egyptian pod-thorn</hi>: Mimosa Nilotica, Linn.; described by <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:24:109 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 24, 12, 67, § 109 sq.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n284.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The juice</hi> or <hi rend="ital">gum</hi> of the same, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:6:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 6, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:233" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 20, 21, 85, § 233</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1011,001:Comp. 23 al" default="NO"><author>Scrib.</author> Comp. 23 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
academia: <entryFree id="n285" type="greek" key="a^ca^de_mi_^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcădēmī^a</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)kadh/meia</foreign>, and less correctly <foreign lang="greek">a)kadhmi/a</foreign>, <sense id="n285.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the Academy</hi>, a gymnasium about six stadia from Athens, named after the hero <hi rend="ital">Academos</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Echedemos</hi> (cf. Plut. Thes. 31), celebrated as the place where Plato taught; whence his scholars were called <hi rend="ital">Academici</hi>, and his doctrine <hi rend="ital">Philosophia Academica</hi>, in distinction from <hi rend="ital">Stoica</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Cynica</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:21:98" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 21, 98</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:3:12" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 3, 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:1:1 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 5, 1, 1 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n285.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Meton.</usg> </sense><sense id="n285.2" n="A" level="2"> For <hi rend="ital">The philosophy of the Academy</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">instaret academia, quae quidquid dixisses, id te ipsum scire negaret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:10:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 10, 43</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:4:20 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3, 4, 20 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Academia vetus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 1, 4, 18</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:8:21" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 5, 8, 21</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">recens,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:1:13:39" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 1, 13, 39</bibl></cit>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">recentior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:18:68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 3, 18, 68</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">and adulescentior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:8:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 9, 8, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nova,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 1, 12, 46 al.</bibl></cit>— </sense><sense id="n285.3" n="B" level="2"> Cicero, as a partisan of the Academic philosophy, named his estate, on the way from Lake Avernus to Puteoli, <hi rend="ital">Academia;</hi> there also he wrote the <hi rend="ital">Academica.</hi> He had another <hi rend="ital">Academia</hi> at his Tusculan Villa, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:3" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 3</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:4:3 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 1, 4, 3 al.</bibl> (The <hi rend="ital">i</hi> long, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:13:22" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 13, 22</bibl>; Tull. Laurea ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:31:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 31, 2, 3, § 8</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">short,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> de Cons. Mall. Theod. 94</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> 15, 120</bibl>.)</sense></entryFree>
academice: <entryFree id="n286" type="spur" key="A^ca^de_mi^ce_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăcădēmĭcē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:13:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 13, 16</bibl>; better written as Greek, <foreign lang="greek">*)akadhmikh\ su/ntacis</foreign>, i. e. <sense id="n286.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Academica</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the Academics</hi>, v. academicus.</sense></entryFree>
academicus: <entryFree id="n287" type="greek" key="a^ca^de_mi^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcădēmĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)kadhmiko/s</foreign>, <sense id="n287.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">relating to the Academy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Academic</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">philosophi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:11:5" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 11, 5</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcă-dēmĭcus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">an Academic philosopher</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:1:1" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 1, 1</bibl>; and in <number>plur.</number>, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 1</bibl>, <cb n="ACAU" /> 1; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 44</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:11:34 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 2, 11, 34 al.</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">hence quaestio,</quote> <trans><tr>inquiry on the Academic philosophy</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:13:19:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 13, 19, 3</bibl></cit> (v. academia, II. B.). —In <hi rend="ital">neutr. plur.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăcădēmĭca</orth>, <hi rend="ital">one of Cicero's writings</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the Academics</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:2:8" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 2, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:13:19:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 13, 19, 5</bibl>; also called <hi rend="ital">Academici libri</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tvsc. 2, 2, 4</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
academus: <entryFree id="n288" type="main" key="A^ca^de_mus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăcădēmus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)aka/dhmos</foreign>, <sense id="n288.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a Grecian hero</hi>, <hi rend="ital">from whom the Academia near Athens is said to have derived its name</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">inter silvas Academi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 2, 45</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
acalanthis: <entryFree id="n289" type="greek" key="a^ca^lanthis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcălanthis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)kalanqi/s</foreign>, i. q. acanthis, <sense id="n289.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a very small bird of a darkgreen color;</hi> according to Voss, <hi rend="ital">the thistlefinch</hi>, <hi rend="ital">goldfinch</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:338" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 338</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acalephe: <entryFree id="n290" type="greek" key="a^ca^le_phe_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcălēphē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)kalh/fh</foreign>, a <sense id="n290.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">nettle</hi>, Macer. de Virt. Herb. 2, 2.</sense></entryFree>
acamas: <entryFree id="n291" type="main" key="A^ca^mas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăcămas</orth>, <itype>antis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)aka/mas</foreign>. <sense id="n291.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A son of Theseus and Phœdra</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:262" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 262</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n291.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A servant of Vulcan</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:1:583" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 1, 583</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n291.2" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A promontory of Cyprus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:129" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 31, 35, § 129</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acanos: <entryFree id="n292" type="greek" key="a^ca^nos"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcănos</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/kanos</foreign>, <sense id="n292.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a plant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a kind of thistle</hi>: Onopordon Acanthium, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:22:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 22, 9, 10, § 23</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acanthice: <entryFree id="n293" type="greek" key="a^canthi^ce_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcanthĭcē mastĭchē</orth> = <foreign lang="greek">a)kanqikh\ masti/xh</foreign>, <sense id="n293.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the juice of the plant</hi> helxine, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 21, 16, 56, § 96</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acanthillis: <entryFree id="n294" type="greek" key="a^canthillis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcanthillis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)kanqilli/s</foreign>, <sense id="n294.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">wild asparagus</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 84</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acanthinus: <entryFree id="n295" type="main" key="a^canthi^nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcanthĭnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>acanthus</etym>, <sense id="n295.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">resembling the plant bear's-foot</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:9:4:4" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 9, 4, 4</bibl>, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:25:78" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 25, 7, 38, § 78</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acanthion: <entryFree id="n296" type="greek" key="a^canthi^on"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcanthĭon</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ka/nqion</foreign>, <sense id="n296.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a species of thistle</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:24:108" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 24, 12, 66, § 108</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acanthis: <entryFree id="n297" type="greek" key="a^canthis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcanthis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)kanqi/s</foreign>. <sense id="n297.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A little bird of a dark-green color</hi>, <hi rend="ital">that lives in the thorn bushes</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the thistle-finch</hi> or <hi rend="ital">goldfinch</hi> (pure Lat. carduelis): Fringilla carduelis, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:175" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 63, 83, § 175</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:205" default="NO" valid="yes">10, 74, 95, § 205</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n297.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A plant</hi>, called also senecio, <hi rend="ital">groundsel</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:25:168" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 25, 13, 106, § 168</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acanthius: <entryFree id="n298" type="main" key="A^canthi^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăcanthĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n298.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">from Acanthus</hi>, a town in Macedonia: <cit><quote lang="la">sal,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:31:85" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 31, 7, 41, § 85</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n298.1" n="1" level="3"> † <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcanthus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/kanqos</foreign>. </sense><sense id="n298.2" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The plant bear's-breech</hi>, <hi rend="ital">bear's-foot</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">brankursine</hi>: Acanthus mollis, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,001:3:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> E. 3, 45</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:123" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 4, 123</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:649" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 1, 649</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:22:76 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 22, 22, 34, § 76 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n298.3" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Fem.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a thorny evergreen tree of Egypt</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:119" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 119</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:56:2" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 56, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:24:12:66 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 24, 12, 66 sq.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
acanthus: <entryFree id="n299" type="main" key="A^canthus" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăcanthus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)/akanqos</foreign>, <sense id="n299.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town of Macedonia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">now Erisso</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:31:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 31, 45 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:2:9" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 2, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 10, 17, § 38</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acanthyllis: <entryFree id="n300" type="greek" key="a^canthyllis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcanthyllis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)kanqulli/s</foreign>, <sense id="n300.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a little bird</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 33, 50, § 96</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acapnos: <entryFree id="n301" type="greek" key="a^capnos"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcapnos</orth>, <itype>on</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/kapnos</foreign>, <sense id="n301.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">without smoke</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ligna acapna,</quote> <trans><tr>wood so dry as to emit no smoke in burning</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:13:15" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 13, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mel acapnon,</quote> <trans><tr>honey obtained without driving away the bees by smoke</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:6:33:2" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 6, 33, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 16, 15, § 45</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acarnan: <entryFree id="n302" type="main" key="A^carna_n"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăcarnān</orth>, <itype>ānis</itype> (<case>acc.</case> Acarnana, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:36:11:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 36, 11, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:37:45:17" default="NO" valid="yes">37, 45, 17</bibl>; <sense id="n302.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">acc. plur.</hi> Acarnanas, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:Epit. 33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Epit. 33</bibl>), <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">pertaining to Acarnania</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Acarnanian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">amnis,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>Acheloüs</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:3:42" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 3, 42</bibl></cit> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:569" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 569</bibl>); <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an Acarnanian</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an inhabitant of Acarnania</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:298" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 298</bibl>; Liv. l. c.; from</sense></entryFree>
acarnania: <entryFree id="n303" type="main" key="A^carna_ni^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăcarnānĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n303.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Acarnania</hi>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)akarnani/a</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">the most westerly province of Greece</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:40:96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 40, 96</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 55</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:25 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 25 al.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:3:4" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 3, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:1:2 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 1, 2 sq.</bibl>—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăcarnānĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">Acarnanian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">conjuratio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:25:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 25, 18</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
acarne: <entryFree id="n304" type="main" key="a^carne_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcarnē</orth>, v. acharne.</entryFree>
acastus: <entryFree id="n305" type="main" key="A^castus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăcastus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)/akastos</foreign>. <sense id="n305.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Son of Pelias</hi>, <hi rend="ital">king of Thessaly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">husband of Astydamia or Cretheis</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and father of Laodamia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:306" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 306</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">11, 410 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n305.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The name of one of Cicero's slaves</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:1 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 7, 1 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
acatalecticus: <entryFree id="n306" type="greek" key="a^ca^ta^le_cti^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcătălēctĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)katalhk-tiko/s,</foreign> <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcătălēctus</orth>, <foreign lang="greek">a)katalhk-to/s</foreign>, in prosody, <sense id="n306.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a verse in which no syllable is wanting in the last foot</hi> (opp. catalecticus), <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> p. 501</bibl> P.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 1216</bibl> P.</sense></entryFree>
acatium: <entryFree id="n307" type="greek" key="a^ca^ti^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcătĭum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ka/tion</foreign>, <sense id="n307.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a light Greek boat</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:94" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 9, 30, 49, § 94</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acatus: <entryFree id="n308" type="greek" key="a^ca^tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcătus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/katos</foreign>, <sense id="n308.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a light vessel</hi> or <hi rend="ital">boat</hi> (pure Latin, actuaria), <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> adv. Marc. 5, 1 <hi rend="ital">med.</hi></bibl></sense></entryFree>
acaunumarga: <entryFree id="n309" type="main" key="acaunumarga"><orth extent="full" lang="la">acaunumarga</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>a Celtic word <pb n="15" /> <cb n="ACCE" /> from agaunum, stone</etym>, <sense id="n309.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kind of marl</hi>, perhaps <hi rend="ital">stone-marl</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 7, 4, § 44</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acaustus: <entryFree id="n310" type="greek" key="a^caustus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcaustus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/kaustos</foreign>, <sense id="n310.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">incombustible;</hi> hence <hi rend="ital">subst. m.</hi> (sc. lapis), <hi rend="ital">the carbuncle</hi>, since it was regarded as incombustible: acaustoe (i. e. <foreign lang="greek">a)/kaustoi</foreign>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:92" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 7, 25, § 92</bibl>; v. Sill. a. h. l.</sense></entryFree>
acbarus: <entryFree id="n311" type="main" key="Acba^rus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Acbărus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n311.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a title of the Arabian kings</hi>, <hi rend="ital">among the Greeks and Romans</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:12:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 12, 12</bibl>; also written Abgarus and Abgar, Capit. Anton. 9; Inscr. Orell. <hi rend="ital">no.</hi> 921.</sense></entryFree>
acca: <entryFree id="n312" type="main" key="Acca"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Acca</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>cf. Sct. accā = mater, and the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">*)akkw/</foreign> = mater Cereris</etym>. <sense id="n312.0" n="I" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Lā-rentĭa</orth>, <hi rend="ital">the wife of the shepherd Faustulus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who nursed and brought up the twins Romulus and Remus; mother of the twelve</hi> Arvales Fratres, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 6:23" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 6, 23</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:6:7" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 6, 7</bibl>. In her honor the Romans celebrated in December a feast called <hi rend="ital">Lārentālĭa</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">Accālĭa</hi> (v. Larentia).—</sense><sense id="n312.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A companion of Camilla</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:820" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 820</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
accalia: <entryFree id="n313" type="main" key="Acca_li^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Accālĭa</orth>, <itype>ĭum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n313.0" n="I" level="1"><xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">the preced. word</ref></xr> and Larentia.</sense></entryFree>
accano: <entryFree id="n314" type="gloss" key="acca^no"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-căno</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-cĭno</orth>, <sense id="n314.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to sing to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">with</hi> any thing, acc. to <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 6:section=75" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 6, § 75</bibl> Müll., and <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> p. 425</bibl> P.</sense></entryFree>
accanto: <entryFree id="n315" type="hapax" key="accanto"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-canto</orth>, <itype>āre, 1</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos>, <sense id="n315.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to sing at</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tumulis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Silv. 4, 4, 55</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
accantus: <entryFree id="n316" type="main" key="accantus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accantus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = accentus, <bibl default="NO"><author>Mart. Cap.</author> 3, p. 60</bibl>; Bed. de Metris, p. 2358 Putsch.</entryFree>
accedenter: <entryFree id="n317" type="hapax" key="acce_denter"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accēdenter</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>accedo</etym>, i. q. prope, <sense id="n317.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">nearly</hi>, Cassiod. (?).</sense></entryFree>
accedo: <entryFree id="n318" type="main" key="acce_do"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-cēdo</orth>, <itype>cessi, cessum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> (<sense id="n318.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">perf. sync.</hi>, accēstis, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:201" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 201</bibl>), <hi rend="ital">to go</hi> or <hi rend="ital">come to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">near</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to approach</hi> (class.). </sense><sense id="n318.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n318.2" n="A" level="2"> In gen., constr. with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in</hi>, the local <hi rend="ital">adverbs</hi>, the <case>acc.</case>, <case>dat.</case>, <hi rend="ital">infin.</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> </sense><sense id="n318.3" n="(a)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">accedam ad hominem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:2:6:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 2, 6, 14</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">ad aedīs,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Amph. 1, 1, 108</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad flammam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ter.</author> Andr. 1, 1, 103</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnīs ad aras,</quote> <trans><tr>to beset every altar</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:1199" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 1199</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad oppidum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad ludos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:27:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 27, 65</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad Caesarem supplex,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:4:4:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 4, 4, 3</bibl></cit>: ad manum, <hi rend="ital">to come to their hands</hi> (of fishes), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:1:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 2, 1, 7</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad Aquinum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:41:106" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 2, 41, 106</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">ad Heracleam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:49:section=129" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 49, § 129</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Impers.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad eas (oleas) cum accederetur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:8:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Caecin. 8, 22</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n318.4" n="(b)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">in</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne in aedīs accederes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:13:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Caecin. 13, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in senatum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:4:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 7, 4, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in Macedoniam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:10:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 10, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in funus aliorum,</quote> <trans><tr>to join a funeral procession</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:26:66 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 2, 26, 66 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n318.5" n="(g)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">local adv.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">eodem pacto, quo huc accessi, abscessero,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:3:2:84" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 3, 2, 84</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">illo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:16:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Caecin. 16, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 14:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 14, 17</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n318.6" n="(d)" level="5"> With <case>acc.</case> (so, except the names of localities, only in poets and historians, but not in Caesar and Livy): <cit><quote lang="la">juvat integros accedere fontīs atque haurire,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:927" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 927</bibl></cit>, and 4, 2: <cit><quote lang="la">Scyllaeam rabiem scopulosque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:201" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 201</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Sicanios portus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:14:3" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 14, 3</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:6:604" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 6, 604</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Africam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Hann. 8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Hann. 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 18:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 18, 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:62:1" default="NO" valid="yes">62, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 24</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">classis Ostia cum magno commeatu accessit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:22:37:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 22, 37, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Carthaginem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:7:27:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 7, 27, 3</bibl></cit>.—（<foreign lang="greek">e</foreign>) With <case>dat.</case> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg>): <cit><quote lang="la">delubris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:745" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 745</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">silvis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:5:674" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 674</bibl></cit>: caelo (i. e. <hi rend="ital">to become a god</hi>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:15:818" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 15, 818</bibl>, and 870.—（* <foreign lang="greek">z</foreign>) With <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">dum constanter accedo decerpere (rosas),</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 4, p. 143 <hi rend="ital">med.</hi></bibl></cit>—（<foreign lang="greek">h</foreign>) <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">accedam atque hanc appellabo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:3:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 3, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">deici nullo modo potuisse qui non accesserit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:13:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Caecin. 13, 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">accessit propius,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 8, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quoties voluit blandis accedere dictis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:3:375 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 3, 375 al.</bibl></cit>—<hi rend="ital">Impers.</hi>: non potis accedi, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:2:16:38" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 2, 16, 38</bibl> (Trag. v. 17 ed. Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">quod eā proxime accedi poterat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:8:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Caecin. 8, 21</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n318.7" n="B" level="2"> In partic. </sense><sense id="n318.8" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To approach a thing in a hostilemanner</hi> (like aggredior, adorior), <hi rend="ital">to attack</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">acie instructa usque ad castra hostium accessit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sese propediem cum magno exercitu ad urbem accessurum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 32 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad manum,</quote> <trans><tr>to fight hand to hand</tr>, <tr>to engage in close combat</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,018:5:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Eum. 5, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:30:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 30, 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad corpus alicujus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:3:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 3, 2, 2</bibl></cit>: Atque accedit muros Romana juventus, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:10:29" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 10, 29</bibl> (Ann. v. 527 ed. Vahl.): hostīs accedere ventis navibus velivolis, id. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 6, 5</bibl> (Ann. v. 380 ib.); <cit><quote lang="la">and, in malam part.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:3:3:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Heaut. 3, 3, 22</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n318.9" n="2" level="3"> <usg type="dom">Mercant. t. t.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">accedere ad hastam,</quote> <trans><tr>to attend an auction</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:6:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Att. 6, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:43:16:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 43, 16, 2</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n318.10" n="3" level="3"> In late Lat.: ad manus (different from ad manum, B. 1), <hi rend="ital">to be admitted to kiss hands</hi>, Capit. <bibl default="NO"><author>Maxim.</author> 5</bibl>. <cb n="ACCE" /></sense><sense id="n318.11" n="II" level="1"> Fig. </sense><sense id="n318.12" n="A" level="2"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">to come near to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to approach</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">haud invito ad aurīs sermo mi accessit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:3:5:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 3, 5, 32</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">clemens quidam sonus aurīs ejus accedit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 5, p. 160</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si somnus non accessit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:3:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 3, 18</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">febris accedit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:3:3 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 3 sq.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ubi accedent anni,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:2:85" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 2, 85</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">accedente senectā,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ep. 2, 2, 211</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n318.13" n="B" level="2"> In partic. </sense><sense id="n318.14" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To come to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">upon</hi> one, <hi rend="ital">to happen to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to befall</hi> (a meaning in which it approaches so near to <hi rend="ital">accĭdo</hi> that in many passages it has been proposed to change it to the latter; cf. Ruhnk. Rut. Lup. 1, p. 3; 2, p. 96; Dictat. in <bibl default="NO"><author>Ter.</author> p. 222</bibl> and 225); constr. with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> or (more usually) with <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">voluntas vostra si ad poëtam accesserit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:prol. 29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. prol. 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">num tibi stultitia accessit?</quote> <trans><tr>have you become a fool?</tr></trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:2:2:77" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 2, 2, 77</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">paulum vobis accessit pecuniae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:3:5:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 3, 5, 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dolor accessit bonis viris, virtus non est imminuta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:16:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 1, 16, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quo plus sibi aetatis accederet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:60:254 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 60, 254 al.</bibl></cit></sense><sense id="n318.15" n="2" level="3"> With the accessory idea of increase, <hi rend="ital">to be added</hi> = addi; constr. with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> or <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: primum facie (i. e. faciei) quod honestas accedit, Lucil. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:1:14" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 1, 14</bibl>; so ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 35, 20</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad virtutis summam accedere nihil potest,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:4:24" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 4, 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Cassio animus accessit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 5, 20</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">7, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:60 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 60 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">pretium agris,</quote> <trans><tr>the price increases</tr>, <tr>advances</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:6:19:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 6, 19, 1</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">plura accedere debent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:1129" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 1129</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">accedit mors,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:1:18:60" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 1, 18, 60</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:17:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 17, 73</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae jacerent in tenebris omnia, nisi litterarum lumen accederet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,016:6:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Arch. 6, 14</bibl></cit> (so, not accenderet, is to be read).—If a new thought is to be added, it is expressed by accedit with quod (<hi rend="ital">add to this</hi>, <hi rend="ital">that</hi>, etc.) when it implies a logical reason, but with ut (<hi rend="ital">beside this</hi>, <hi rend="ital">it happens that</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">it occurs that</hi>) when it implies an historical fact (cf. Zumpt, § <cit><quote lang="la">621 and 626): accedit enim, quod patrem amo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:13:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 13, 21</bibl></cit>: so Cael. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:8:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 8, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:8:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Am. 8, 22</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:92 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 1, 92 al.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 3, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">4, 16</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 11:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 11, 5</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">on the other hand: huc accedit uti, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:192:215:265 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 192, 215, 265 al.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad App. Claudii senectutem accedebat etiam ut caecus esset,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> de Sen. 6, 16</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:19:43" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 1, 19, 43</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:31:86" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 31, 86</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,034:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Deiot. 1, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:3:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 3, 13</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 16 al.</bibl> When several new ideas are added, they are introduced by <hi rend="ital">res</hi> in the plur.: cum ad has suspiciones certissimae res accederent: quod per fines Sequanorum Helvetios transduxisset; quod obsides inter eos dandos curāsset; <cit><quote lang="la">quod ea omnia, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 19</bibl></cit>. Sometimes the historical idea follows accedit, without ut: <cit><quote lang="la">ad haec mala hoc mihi accedit etiam: haec Andria ... gravida e Pamphilo est,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ter.</author> Andr. 1, 3, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">accedit illud: si maneo ... cadendum est in unius potestatem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:8:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 8, 3, 1</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n318.16" n="3" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To give assent to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">accede to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">assent to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to agree with</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to approve of;</hi> constr. with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> or <case>dat.</case> (with persons only, with <case>dat.</case>): <cit><quote lang="la">accessit animus ad meam sententiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:7:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 2, 7, 13</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:28:section=69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 28, § 69</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:3:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Milt. 3, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Galba speciosiora suadentibus accessit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 34</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:4:2 al" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 9, 4, 2 al.</bibl></sense><sense id="n318.17" n="4" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To come near to in resemblance</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to resemble</hi>, <hi rend="ital">be like;</hi> with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> or <case>dat.</case> (the latter most freq., esp. after Cic.): <cit><quote lang="la">homines ad Deos nulla re propius accedunt quam salutem hominibus dando,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,033:chapter=12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Lig. 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Antonio Philippus proximus accedebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=147" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 147</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:62:263" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 62, 263</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 11, 36 al.</bibl></sense><sense id="n318.18" n="5" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To enter upon</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to undertake;</hi> constr. with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> or <hi rend="ital">in</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in eandem infamiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:1:2:84" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 1, 2, 84</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad bellorum pericula,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,026:chapter=10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Balb. 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad poenam,</quote> <trans><tr>to undertake the infliction of punishment</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:25:89" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 1, 25, 89</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad amicitiam Caesaris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 48</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad vectiǵalia,</quote> <trans><tr>to undertake their collection as contractor</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad causam,</quote> <trans><tr>the direction of a lawsuit</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 2, 38</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:38:175 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 38, 175 al.</bibl> But esp.: <cit><quote lang="la">ad rem publicam,</quote> <trans><tr>to enter upon the service of the state</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:9:28" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 9, 28</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:1 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 1 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
acceleratio: <entryFree id="n319" type="hapax" key="acce^le^ra_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accĕlĕrātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>accelero</etym>, <sense id="n319.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a hastening</hi>, <hi rend="ital">acceleration</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">orationis enuntiandae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 3, 13, 23</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
accelero: <entryFree id="n320" type="main" key="acce^le^ro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-cĕlĕro</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum</itype> (also <orth extent="full" lang="la">adc-</orth>), <itype>1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> and <gen>n.</gen> <sense id="n320.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Act.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to hasten</hi>, <hi rend="ital">accelerate</hi>: gressum adcelerāsse decet, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 89, 25</bibl> (R<bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Trag. Rel. p. 139</bibl>); so, <cit><quote lang="la">gradum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 43</bibl></cit>, <cb n="ACCE" /> 8: <cit><quote lang="la">mortem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:772" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 772</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">iter,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:2:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 2, 39</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:31:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 31, 29</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">oppugnationem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:12:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 12, 46</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">consulatum alicui,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 75</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Pass.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,001:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> Agr. 43</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:85" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 2, 85</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 1, 50</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n320.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Neutr.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to hasten</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to make haste</hi>: si adcelerare volent, ad vesperam consequentur, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:4:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 2, 4, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ipse quoque sibi acceleraret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:22:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Att. 22, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:27:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 27, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:675" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 675</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">9, 221, 505</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:2:74 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 2, 17, 14, § 74 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad aliquem opprimendum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:47:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 27, 47, 8</bibl></cit>.—With local <hi rend="ital">accus.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Cremonam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:100" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 100</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Impers.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quantum accelerari posset,</quote> <trans><tr>as speedily as possible</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:46:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 46, 5</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
accendium: <entryFree id="n321" type="hapax" key="accendi^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accendĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>accendo</etym>, <sense id="n321.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kindling</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a setting on fire</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Sol.</author> 5 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></sense></entryFree>
accendo: <entryFree id="n322" type="main" key="accendo1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accendo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>2. accendo</etym>, <sense id="n322.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an inciter</hi>, <hi rend="ital">instigator;</hi> read by Salmasius in <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> de Pall. 6</bibl>, where the old reading <hi rend="ital">cerdo</hi> is to be preferred.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n323" type="main" key="accendo2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-cendo</orth>, <itype>ndi, nsum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>cf. candeo</etym>, prop. <sense id="n323.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to kindle any thing above</hi>, <hi rend="ital">so that it may burn downwards</hi> (on the contr., <hi rend="ital">succendere</hi>, to kindle underneath, so that it may burn upwards; and <hi rend="ital">incendere</hi>, to set fire to on every side) (class., esp. in the <hi rend="ital">trop.</hi> signif., very freq.). </sense><sense id="n323.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to set on fire</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to kindle</hi>, <hi rend="ital">light</hi>: ut Pergama accensa est, Liv. Andr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 512, 31</bibl> (R<bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Trag. Rel. p. 1</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">faces accensae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:chapter=5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 5</bibl></cit>: lumen de suo lumine, <hi rend="ital">to kindle</hi>, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:16:51" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 16, 51</bibl> (Trag. v. 388 ed. Vahl.); cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">ita res accendent lumina rebus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">Deus solem quasi lumen accendit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,072:9:28" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Univ. 9, 28</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">ignem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:4 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 4 al.</bibl></cit></sense><sense id="n323.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Meton.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to light up</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to illuminate</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">luna radiis solis accensa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:6:17" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 6, 17</bibl></cit> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:31:87" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 1, 31, 87</bibl>); <cit><quote lang="la">so of the lustre of gold: et gemmis galeam clypeumque accenderat auro,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:15:681" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 15, 681</bibl></cit> (but in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,016:6:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Arch. 6, 14</bibl>, the correct read. is accederet, v. Halm a. h. l.).</sense><sense id="n323.3" n="II" level="1"> Fig., <hi rend="ital">to inflame</hi> a person or thing (by any thing), <hi rend="ital">to set on fire</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to kindle</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to incite</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rouse up;</hi> aliquem or aliquid aliqua re: placare hostem ferocem inimiciterque accensum, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 514, 22</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quos meritā accendit Mezentius irā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nunc prece nunc dictis virtutem accendit amaris,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 10, 368</bibl></cit> (7, 482, bello animos accendit, is more properly <case>dat.</case>). That to which one is excited is denoted by <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad dominationem accensi sunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:Jug. 31:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> Jug. 31, 16</bibl></cit>; the person against whom one is excited, by <hi rend="ital">in</hi> or <hi rend="ital">contra</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in maritum accendebat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae res Marium contra Metellum vehementer accenderat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 64:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 64, 4</bibl></cit>; with <hi rend="ital">quare c. subj.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">accendis quare cupiam magis illi proximus esse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:9:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 9, 53</bibl></cit>. The historians use this word very often, esp. with abstract substt.: <cit><quote lang="la">certamen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:35:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 35, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">discordiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">spem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tac.</author> Ann. 12, 34</bibl></cit> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:183" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 183</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">dolorem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 15, 1</bibl></cit> al. In <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:25:114" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 25, 114</bibl>, praeclare enim se res habeat, si haec accendi aut commoveri arte possint, <hi rend="ital">accendi</hi> is obviously the first enkindling, rousing, of talent (syn. with commoveri); cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 47</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:3:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 3, 7</bibl>. And so perhaps <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ben. 7:9" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ben. 7, 9</bibl>: crystallina ... quorum accendit fragilitas pretium, signifies <hi rend="ital">vessels of crystal</hi>, <hi rend="ital">whose fragility gives them value</hi> (in the eyes of luxurious men).</sense></entryFree>
accenseo: <entryFree id="n324" type="main" key="accense^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-censĕo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">ŭi</orth>), <itype>nsum, 2</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n324.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to reckon to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">among</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to add to;</hi> as a <hi rend="ital">verb. finit.</hi> very rare: <cit><quote lang="la">numine sub dominae lateo atque accenseor illi,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>I am her companion</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:546" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 546</bibl></cit>; and: <hi rend="ital">accensi</hi>, qui his accensebantur, id est attribuebantur, <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 520, 7</bibl>.—But hence in frequent use, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-census</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">reckoned among</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi> <orth extent="full" lang="la">accensus</orth>, i., <gen>m.</gen> </sense><sense id="n324.1" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">One who attends</hi> another of higher rank, <hi rend="ital">an attendant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">follower;</hi> hence, <hi rend="ital">a state officer who attended one of the highest magistrates</hi> (consul, proconsul, praetor, etc.) at Rome or in the provinces, for the purpose of summoning parties to court, maintaining order and quiet during its sessions, and proclaiming the hours; <hi rend="ital">an apparitor</hi>, <hi rend="ital">attendant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">orderly</hi> (on account of this office, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:6:section=89" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> 6, § 89</bibl> Müll., would derive the word from <hi rend="ital">accieo</hi>), Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 59, 2 sq.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:1:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 1, 1, 4</bibl> and 7; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:4:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 4, 16</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:45:29:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 45, 29, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:20 al" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 20 al.</bibl>—The person to whom one is accensus is annexed in <case>dat.</case> or <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">qui tum accensus Neroni fuit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">libertus, accensus Gabinii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:4:16:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 4, 16, 12</bibl></cit>. The Decurions and Centurions also <pb n="16" /> <cb n="ACCE" /> had their <hi rend="ital">accensi</hi> as <hi rend="ital">aids</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 7:section=58" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 7, § 58</bibl> Müll.; <cit><quote lang="la">also at funerals, as leader of the procession,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:24:61" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 2, 24, 61</bibl></cit>. Cf. on the accensi, Necker's Antiq. 2, 2, p. 375 sq.— </sense><sense id="n324.2" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">accensi</orth>, <hi rend="ital">a kind of reserve troops who followed the army as supernumeraries</hi> (= <hi rend="ital">ascripticii</hi>, or, in later times, <hi rend="ital">supernumerarii</hi>), to take the place of those who fell in battle. They had no arms, and were only clothed with the military cloak, and hence called <hi rend="ital">velati</hi>: quia vestiti et inermes sequuntur exercitum, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=369" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 369</bibl> Müll.; they used in battle only slings and stones. They were also employed in constructing public roads. Cf. Mommsen, <hi rend="ital">Degli Accensi Velati</hi>, in Annali del. Inst. vol. xxi. (1849), p. 209 sq.; and Necker's Antiq. 3, 2, p. 242 sq.</sense></entryFree>
accensibilis: <entryFree id="n325" type="main" key="accensi^bi^lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accensĭbĭlis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, prop. <sense id="n325.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that may be burnt</hi>, but in the one place where it occurs, it is <hi rend="ital">act.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">burning</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Non accessistis ad accensibilem ignem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Hebr. 12, 18</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
accensus: <entryFree id="n326" type="main" key="accensus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accensus</orth>, <itype>a</itype>, um. <sense id="n326.0" n="a" level="4"> <mood>Part.</mood> of accendo, <hi rend="ital">kindled.</hi>—</sense><sense id="n326.1" n="b" level="4"> <pos>P. a.</pos> of accenseo, <hi rend="ital">reckoned among;</hi> <xr><lbl>v.</lbl> <ref type="sym" targOrder="U">these words</ref></xr>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n327" type="main" key="accensus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accensus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>accendo</etym>, <sense id="n327.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kindling</hi> or <hi rend="ital">setting on fire</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">lucernarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:103" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 7, 29, § 103</bibl></cit> dub. (al. assensu): <cit><quote lang="la">luminum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:3:48" default="NO"><author>Symm.</author> 3, 48</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:7:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 7, 29</bibl>, acc. to Hard.</sense></entryFree>
accentiuncula: <entryFree id="n328" type="hapax" key="accenti^uncu^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accentĭuncŭla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <sense id="n328.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">dim. f.</hi> [accentus], <hi rend="ital">accent</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:13:6" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 13, 6</bibl>, as a transl. of the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">proswdi/a</foreign>.</sense></entryFree>
accentor: <entryFree id="n329" type="main" key="accentor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-centor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>ad + cantor</etym>, <sense id="n329.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one who sings with another</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 6, 19, 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
accentus: <entryFree id="n330" type="main" key="accentus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accentus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>accino, the attuning a thing; hence</etym> <sense id="n330.0" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n330.1" n="A" level="2"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">a blast</hi>, <hi rend="ital">signal</hi> (late Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">aeneatorum accentu,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 16, 12, 36</bibl></cit>: <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> 24, 4, 22</bibl>; acutissimi tibiarum, Solin. 5 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>—</sense><sense id="n330.2" n="B" level="2"> In gramm., <hi rend="ital">the accentuation of a word</hi>, <hi rend="ital">accent</hi>, <hi rend="ital">tone</hi> (post-Aug.): accentus, quos Graeci <foreign lang="greek">proswdi/as</foreign> vocant (so that it is a lit. transl. of the Gr. word, <foreign lang="greek">pro/s</foreign> = ad, and <foreign lang="greek">w)|dh/</foreign> = cantus), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:5:22" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 5, 22</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:10:33" default="NO">12, 10, 33</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> p. 425</bibl> Putsch.—</sense><sense id="n330.3" n="II" level="1"> Fig., <hi rend="ital">intensity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">violence</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">hiemis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Ep. 4, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">doloris,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Marc. Emp.</author> 36</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
accepso: <entryFree id="n331" type="main" key="accepso"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accepso</orth>, per sync. for accepero, v. accipio.</entryFree>
accepta: <entryFree id="n332" type="main" key="accepta"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accepta</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>accipio</etym> (sc. pars), <sense id="n332.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a portion of land granted to an individual by the state</hi>, Sicul. Fl. p. 22 Goed. al.</sense></entryFree>
acceptabilis: <entryFree id="n333" type="main" key="accepta_bi^lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">acceptābĭlis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>accepto</etym>, <sense id="n333.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">acceptable</hi>, <hi rend="ital">worthy of acceptance</hi> (eccl. Lat.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> de Or. 7 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
acceptator: <entryFree id="n334" type="main" key="accepta_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">acceptātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n334.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">One who accepts or approves</hi> of a thing (Eccl.).—</sense><sense id="n334.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An avenue</hi>, <hi rend="ital">access</hi>, <hi rend="ital">passage for admittance of the people</hi>, Inscr Orell. <hi rend="ital">no.</hi> 6589.</sense></entryFree>
acceptilatio: <entryFree id="n335" type="main" key="accepti^la_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">acceptĭlātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis, also written separately, accepti latio</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>acceptum fero</etym>, <sense id="n335.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a formal discharging from a debt</hi> (by the verbal declaration of the debtor: <cit><quote lang="la">acceptum fero),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1251,001:3:169" default="NO"><author>Gai.</author> 3, 169</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1251,001:170" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 170</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:4:2:9:section=2" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 4, 2, 9, § 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:34:3:3:section=3" default="NO">34, 3, 3, § 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:Lex. 5:section=3 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Lex. 5, § 3 al.</bibl>; cf. Rein's Privatrecht, p. 359.</sense></entryFree>
acceptio: <entryFree id="n336" type="main" key="accepti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">acceptĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>accipio</etym>. <sense id="n336.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A taking</hi>, <hi rend="ital">receiving</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">accepting</hi>: neque deditionem neque donationem sine acceptione intellegi posse, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,042:8:37" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Top. 8, 37</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">frumenti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 29:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 29, 4</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n336.1" n="B" level="2"> In later philos. lang.: <hi rend="ital">the acceptance</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">the granting of a proposition</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Pseudo</author> App. Dogm. Plat. 3, p. 34 <hi rend="ital">med.</hi></bibl>—</sense><sense id="n336.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An esteeming</hi>, <hi rend="ital">regarding</hi>: of a thing, Cod. Th. 1, 9, 2; <cit><quote lang="la">of a person: personarum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Paral. 2, 19, 7</bibl></cit> (transl. of<foreign />); cf. 1. acceptor, <hi rend="ital">no.</hi> II. B.</sense></entryFree>
acceptito: <entryFree id="n337" type="hapax" key="accepti^to"><orth extent="full" lang="la">acceptĭto</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <sense id="n337.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">doub. freq. v. a.</hi> [fr. accepto, and that fr. accipio], <hi rend="ital">to take</hi>, <hi rend="ital">receive</hi>, <hi rend="ital">accept</hi>: stipendium, Plaut. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 134, 29</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
accepto: <entryFree id="n338" type="main" key="accepto"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accepto</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. freq. a.</pos> <etym>accipio</etym>, <sense id="n338.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to take</hi>, <hi rend="ital">receive</hi>, <hi rend="ital">accept</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">argentum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:2:2:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 2, 2, 32</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:7:9" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 7, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:6:5" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 6, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:34:1:9" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 34, 1, 9</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">jugum,</quote> <trans><tr>to submit to</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:Ital. 7:41" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> Ital. 7, 41</bibl></cit>. (But in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:25:64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 25, 64</bibl>, the correct read. is coeptavere; v. Sillig. a. h. l.).</sense></entryFree>
acceptor: <entryFree id="n339" type="main" key="acceptor1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">acceptor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>. <sense id="n339.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">One who receives a thing</hi> (post-class.): donationis, Cod. T. 8, 56, 10.—Hence, <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a receiver</hi>, <hi rend="ital">collector</hi>, Inscr. Orell. <hi rend="ital">no.</hi> 3199 and 7205.—</sense><sense id="n339.1" n="II" level="1"> Fig. </sense><sense id="n339.2" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">One who receives a thing as true</hi>, <hi rend="ital">grants</hi> or <hi rend="ital">approves it</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:1:2:167" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 1, 2, 167</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n339.3" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">One who unjustly regards the person</hi>, Eccl. <cb n="ACCI" /></sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n340" type="main" key="acceptor2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">acceptor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = accipiter, <sense id="n340.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a hawk</hi>: exta acceptoris, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 76</bibl> P.</sense></entryFree>
acceptorius: <entryFree id="n341" type="hapax" key="accepto_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">acceptōrĭus</orth>, <itype>a</itype>, um. <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>acceptor</etym>, <sense id="n341.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that is fit</hi> or <hi rend="ital">suitable for receiving</hi>: modulus, <hi rend="ital">for drawing water</hi>, Frontin. de Aq. 34 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
acceptrix: <entryFree id="n342" type="hapax" key="acceptrix"><orth extent="full" lang="la">acceptrix</orth>, <itype>īcis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n342.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">she that receives</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque datori neque acceptrici,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:2:7:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 2, 7, 18</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
acceptum: <entryFree id="n343" type="main" key="acceptum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">acceptum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, v. accipio, II. E.</entryFree>
acceptus: <entryFree id="n344" type="main" key="acceptus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">acceptus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, v. <itype>accipio</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos></entryFree>
accerso: <entryFree id="n345" type="main" key="accerso"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accerso</orth>, <itype>ĕre</itype>, v. arcesso <sense id="n345.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">init.</hi></sense></entryFree>
accessa: <entryFree id="n346" type="hapax" key="accessa"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accessa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, in later Lat. = accessus, <sense id="n346.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the flood-tide</hi>, lect. dub., <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 1, 244</bibl> (cf. Salmas. Exerc. p. 203).</sense></entryFree>
accessibilis: <entryFree id="n347" type="main" key="accessi^bi^lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accessĭbĭlis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>accedo</etym>, <sense id="n347.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">accessible</hi> (late Lat.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Adv. Prax. 15</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
accessibilitas: <entryFree id="n348" type="main" key="accessi^bi^li^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accessĭbĭlĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>accessibilis</etym>, <sense id="n348.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">accessibility</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Adv. Prax. 15</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
accessio: <entryFree id="n349" type="main" key="accessi^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accessĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>accedo</etym>, <sense id="n349.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a going</hi> or <hi rend="ital">coming to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">near</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an approach.</hi> </sense><sense id="n349.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">quid tibi in concilium huc accessio est?</quote> <trans><tr>why comest thou hither?</tr></trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:3:2:86" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 3, 2, 86</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">quid tibi ad hasce accessio est aedīs prope?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:2:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Truc. 2, 2, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,072:chapter=12" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Univ. 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut magnas accessiones fecerint in operibus expugnandis,</quote> <trans><tr>sallies</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Caes.</author> B. Alex. 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">suo labore suisque accessionibus,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>by his labor of calling on people</tr>, <tr>by his visits</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 53 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n349.2" n="II" level="1"> In part. </sense><sense id="n349.3" n="A" level="2"> In medicine, t. t., <hi rend="ital">the access</hi>, <hi rend="ital">attack</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">paroxysm of a disease</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:2:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 2, 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:3:3" default="NO" valid="yes">3, 3</bibl> sq.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 85:12" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 85, 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:N. Q. 6:18:6" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. Q. 6, 18, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=vesp.:23 al" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Vesp. 23 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n349.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A coming to in the way of augmentation</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an increase</hi>, <hi rend="ital">addition.</hi> </sense><sense id="n349.5" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">In abstracto</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">paucorum annorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:3:7" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Lael. 3, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecuniae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:14:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Att. 14, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">fortunae et dignitatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:2:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 2, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">7, 6</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">10, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:2:21" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 2, 21</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">odii,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Caes.</author> B.
