Alex. 48</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dignitatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:130" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 130 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n349.6" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">The thing added</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the addition</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">accession: in concreto</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Scaurusaccessionem adjunxit aedibus,</quote> <trans><tr>added a new part</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:39:138" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 39, 138</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:16:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 16, 16</bibl>. Thus Syphax is called, accessio Punici belli, as not being the chief enemy in the Punic war, but, as it were, an appendage to the war, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:47:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 47, 7</bibl>; so in Pliny: turbā gemmarum potamus—et aurum jam accessio est, <hi rend="ital">and gold is only accessory</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a mere appendage</hi>, 33 prooem. <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>— </sense><sense id="n349.7" n="C" level="2"> In rhetor., <hi rend="ital">an addition that makes a definition complete</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nisi adhiberet illam magnam accessionem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 35, 112</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:13" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 2, 13</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n349.8" n="D" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The addition to every kind of fee</hi> or <hi rend="ital">tax</hi> (opp. <hi rend="ital">decessio</hi>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0022,001:144" default="NO"><author>Cato</author> R. R. 144</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">decumae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rab. 11</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:33:section=116 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 33, § 116 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
accessito: <entryFree id="n350" type="hapax" key="accessi^to"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accessĭto</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, <sense id="n350.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">doub. freq. v.</hi> [id.], <hi rend="ital">to approach repeatedly</hi>: eodem ex agro, Cat. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:18:12" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 18, 12</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
accessus: <entryFree id="n351" type="main" key="accessus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accessus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> of accedo.</entryFree>

<entryFree id="n352" type="main" key="accessus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accessus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>accedo</etym>, <sense id="n352.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a going</hi> or <hi rend="ital">coming to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">near</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an approaching</hi>, <hi rend="ital">approach</hi> (syn. aditus; opp. recessus, discessus). </sense><sense id="n352.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">accessus nocturnus ad urbem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:chapter=19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mil. 19</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">(bestiarum) ad res salutares (opp. recessus),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:12" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 12 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">accessus prohibet refugitque viriles,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:636" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 636</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">solisaccessus discessusque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:7" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 7</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">of the tide,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:14" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 2, 14 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">of a disease,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:4:2" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 4, 2</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">of soldiers: difficilis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Caes.</author> B. Afr. 5</bibl></cit>: maritimus, <hi rend="ital">from the sea</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pedestris,</quote> <trans><tr>on the land side</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> B. Alex. 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">loci,</quote> <trans><tr>to a place</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> B. Hisp. 38</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n352.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n352.3" n="1" level="3"> <usg type="style">Poet.</usg> of permission to approach, <hi rend="ital">access</hi>, <hi rend="ital">admittance</hi> (cf. aditus): <cit><quote lang="la">dare accessum alicui,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Pont. 2, 2, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">negare,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Her. 10, 64</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n352.4" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">The place by which one approaches</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a passage</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an entrance</hi> (in <number>sing.</number> and <number>plur.</number>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:229" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 229</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:58" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 58</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:2:12:5" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 2, 12, 5</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">for ships,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:29:27:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 29, 27, 9</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n352.5" n="II" level="1"> Fig. </sense><sense id="n352.6" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">An approaching</hi>, <hi rend="ital">approach</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ita pedetemptim cum accessus a se ad causam facti, tum recessus,</quote> <trans><tr>an approach to the matter</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:14:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 9, 14, 7</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n352.7" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">An accession</hi>, <hi rend="ital">increase</hi>: accessu istius splendoris, Cod. Th. 6, 35, 7.</sense></entryFree>
accianus: <entryFree id="n353" type="main" key="Acci^a_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Accĭānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, v. Attius (Attianus).</entryFree>
accidens: <entryFree id="n354" type="main" key="acci^dens"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accĭdens</orth>, entis. <sense id="n354.0" n="I" level="1"> <pos>P. a.</pos> fr. accĭdo.— </sense><sense id="n354.1" n="II" level="1"> As <hi rend="ital">subst. n.</hi> </sense><sense id="n354.2" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The accidental</hi>, <hi rend="ital">nonessential quality</hi> of any thing, <foreign lang="greek">tò sumbebhko/s</foreign> (opp. substantia, the Greek <foreign lang="greek">ou)si/a</foreign>): causa, tempus, locus, occasio . . . rerum sunt accidentia, <hi rend="ital">the accidental</hi> or <hi rend="ital">extraneous circumstances</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:5:10:23" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 5, 10, 23</bibl>; so 3, 6, 36; 4, 2, 130: ex accidentibus (= epithetis),<cb n="ACCI" />  <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:3:70" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 8, 3, 70</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">hence,</quote> <trans><tr>an adjective</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 1, 4</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n354.3" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">An accident</hi> or <hi rend="ital">chance.</hi> </sense><sense id="n354.4" n="1" level="3"> In gen., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:35:2:51" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 35, 2, 51</bibl>: per accidens, <hi rend="ital">accidentally</hi>, Firm. Math. 5, 4.—</sense><sense id="n354.5" n="2" level="3"> In part., <hi rend="ital">an unfortunate circumstance</hi>: accidentia (opp. prospera), Pseudo-Quint. Decl.</sense></entryFree>
accidentia: <entryFree id="n355" type="main" key="acci^denti^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accĭdentĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>accĭdo</etym>, <sense id="n355.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that which happens</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a casual event</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a chance</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">esse illam naturae accidentiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:32:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 32, 2, 9, § 19</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> de Anim. 11 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
accido: <entryFree id="n356" type="main" key="acci_do1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-cīdo</orth>, <itype>cīdi, cīsum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>caedo</etym>, <sense id="n356.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to begin to cut</hi> or <hi rend="ital">to cut into</hi> [cf.: adamo, addubito, etc.); hence, <hi rend="ital">so to cut a thing that it falls</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to fell</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to cut</hi> (as <hi rend="ital">verb. finit.</hi> very rare). </sense><sense id="n356.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">accidunt arbores, tantum ut summa species earum stantium relinquatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:6:27:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 6, 27, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">accisa ornus ferro,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:626" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 626</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">velut accisis recrescenti stirpibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:41:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 41, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">accisis crinibus,</quote> <trans><tr>cut close</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 19</bibl></cit>: ab locustis genus omne acciditur frugum, <hi rend="ital">eaten up</hi>, Arnob. 1, 3.—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to use up</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">fames accisis coget dapibus consumere mensas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:125" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 125</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n356.2" n="II" level="1"> Fig., <hi rend="ital">to impair</hi>, <hi rend="ital">weaken</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ita proelio uno accidit Vestinorum res, ut, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:29:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 29, 12</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">post accisas a Camillo Volscorum res,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:5:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 6, 5, 2</bibl></cit>; cf. 6, 12, 6.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">accīsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">cut off</hi> or <hi rend="ital">down; impaired</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ruined</hi>: accisae res (opp. integrae), <hi rend="ital">troubled</hi>, <hi rend="ital">disordered</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">unfortunate state of things</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">res,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,025:14:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Prov. Cons. 14, 34</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:10:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 10, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:11:12 al" default="NO" valid="yes">8, 11, 12 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">copiae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0530,001:B. G. 8:31" default="NO"><author>Hirt.</author> B. G. 8, 31</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:11:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 11, 8</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">robur juventutis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 7, 29 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">opes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:2:114" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 2, 114</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">accisae desolataeque gentes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:8:590" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 8, 590</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">reliquiae (hostium),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 61</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n357" type="main" key="acci^do2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-cĭdo</orth>, <itype>cīdi</itype>, no <sense id="n357.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">sup.</hi>, <itype>3</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> <etym>cado</etym>, <hi rend="ital">to fall upon</hi> or <hi rend="ital">down upon</hi> a thing, <hi rend="ital">to reach</hi> it <hi rend="ital">by falling.</hi> </sense><sense id="n357.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n357.2" n="A" level="2"> In gen. constr. with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in</hi>, <hi rend="ital">local adverbs</hi>, with <case>dat.</case> or <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>: utinam ne accidisset abiegna ad terram trabes, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 2, 22</bibl> (Trag. p. 281 ed. Vahl., where it is: accĕdisset, acc. to the MSS., v. Vahl. <hi rend="ital">N. v.</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">signa de caelo ad terram,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:prol. 8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. prol. 8</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">tam crebri ad terram accidebant quam pira,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:2:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Poen. 2, 38</bibl></cit>: trabs in humum accidens, Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 494 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">imago aetheris ex oris in terrarum accidat oras,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:215" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 215</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rosa in mensas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:5:360" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 5, 360</bibl></cit>: quo Castalia per struices saxeas lapsu accidit, Liv. Andr. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=310" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 310</bibl> Müll. (R<bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:Trag. Rel. p. 5" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Trag. Rel. p. 5</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">ut missa tela gravius acciderent,</quote> <trans><tr>fall upon</tr>, <tr>hit</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:3:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 3, 14</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:50:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 50, 7</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n357.3" n="B" level="2"> Esp.: a. ad genua or genibus, of a suppliant, <hi rend="ital">to fall at one's knees</hi>: me orat mulier lacrimansque ad genua accidit, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 517, 15</bibl> (Com. v. 9 ed. Vahl.); so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:3:3:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 3, 3, 18</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:20" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:10" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Claud. 10</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">for which: genibus praetoris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:44:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 44, 31</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">also: ad pedes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:14:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 1, 14, 5</bibl></cit>, and <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>: quo accĭdam? quo applicem? Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:19:44" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 3, 19, 44</bibl> (Trag. v. 114 ed. Vahl., where it is accĕdam).—</sense><sense id="n357.4" n="C" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to strike the senses</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to reach a thing by means of the senses;</hi> constr. with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>, the <case>dat.</case> or <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: vox, sermo accidit ad aurīs (or auribus; also, aurīs alicujus), <hi rend="ital">the voice</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the speech falls upon</hi> or <hi rend="ital">reaches the ear</hi>: nota vox ad aurīs accidit, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 39, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nova res molitur ad aurīs accidere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:1024" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 1024</bibl></cit>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">nihil tam populare ad populi Romani aurīs accidisse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:50:107" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sest. 50, 107</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">auribus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:46:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 24, 46, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:10:75" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 10, 75</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aurīs,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:1:2:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Stich. 1, 2, 31</bibl></cit>; <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:5:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 10, 5, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:15:16" default="NO" valid="yes">27, 15, 16</bibl> sq.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:4:5 al" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 4, 5 al.</bibl>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">also: clamor accidit ad aurīs,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:40:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 40, 10</bibl></cit>; and <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">clamor accidit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:33:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 4, 33, 9</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:32:2" default="NO" valid="yes">40, 32, 2</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">likewise: nomen famaque alicujus accidit ad aliquem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:10:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 21, 10, 12</bibl></cit>; v. Fabri ad h. l.—Hence sometimes in Livy: vox <hi rend="ital">or</hi> fama accidit (ad aurīs <hi rend="ital">or</hi> ad aliquem), with an <hi rend="ital">acc. c. inf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut vox etiam ad hostes accideret captum Cominium esse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:10:41:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 10, 41, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quia repente fama accidit classem Punicam adventare,</quote> <trans><tr>the report came</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:29:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 27, 29, 7</bibl></cit>; v. Weissenb. a. h. l.</sense><sense id="n357.5" n="II" level="1"> Fig. </sense><sense id="n357.6" n="A" level="2"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">to fall out</hi>, <hi rend="ital">come to pass</hi>, <hi rend="ital">happen</hi>, <hi rend="ital">occur;</hi> and with <hi rend="ital">dat. pers.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to happen to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to befall</hi> one. (The distinction between the syn. evenio, accido, and contingo is this: <hi rend="ital">evenio</hi>, i. e. ex-venio, is used of either fortunate or unfortunate events: <hi rend="ital">accido</hi>, of occurrences which take us by surprise; hence it is used either of an indifferent, or, which is its general use, of an unfortunate occurrence: <hi rend="ital">contingo</hi>, i. e. contango, indicates that an event accords with <pb n="17" /> <cb n="ACCI" /> one's wishes; and hence is generally used of fortunate events. As Isid. says, Differ. 1: <hi rend="ital">Contingunt</hi> bona: <hi rend="ital">accidunt</hi> mala: <hi rend="ital">eveniunt</hi> utraque): <cit><quote lang="la">res accidit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 14</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">Id acciderat, ut Galli consilium caperent,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 3, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si quid adversi acciderit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 38, 121</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 1, 26, 57</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nollem accidisset tempus, in quo, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 3, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si qua calamitas accidisset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 55</bibl></cit>: <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:chapter=34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 34</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">contra opinionem accidit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 3, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pejus Sequanis accidit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 1, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">periculum accidit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 3, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">detrimentum accidit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 7, 52</bibl></cit>. Also of fortunate occurrences: <cit><quote lang="la">omnia tibi accidisse gratissima,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 3, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">11, 15</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">accidit satis opportune,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:4:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 4, 22</bibl></cit>; cf. Brem. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Milt. 1, 1</bibl>; Herz. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 3</bibl>.—Constr. with <hi rend="ital">ut</hi> (Zumpt, § 621), sometimes with <hi rend="ital">quod</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">accidit perincommode, quod eum nusquam vidisti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 1, 17</bibl></cit>; or with <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec enim acciderat mihi opus esse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:6:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 6, 11</bibl></cit>. Pleonast. in narrations: accidit ut, <hi rend="ital">it happened</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">came to pass</hi>, <hi rend="ital">that</hi>: accidit ut una nocte omnes Hermae dejicerentur, <hi rend="ital">it happened that</hi>, etc., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,007:3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Alc. 3, 2</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:8:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 3, 8, 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:5:4 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 1, 5, 4 al.</bibl>— </sense><sense id="n357.7" n="B" level="2"> In part. </sense><sense id="n357.8" n="1" level="3"> Si quid cui accidat, <hi rend="ital">or</hi> si quid humanitus accidat, euphemist. for <hi rend="ital">to die; if any thing should happen to one</hi> (for which Ennius says: <cit><quote lang="la">si quid me fuerit humanitus, Ann. v. 128 ed. Vahl.): si quid pupillo accidisset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:21" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Inv. 2, 21</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 18</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">si quid mihi humanitus accidisset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 1, 4</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:34:4:30" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 34, 4, 30</bibl> § 2 al. (cf. the Greek <foreign lang="greek">ei)/ ti pa/qoi</foreign>); so, <hi rend="ital">per aposiopesin</hi>, sive—quod heu timeo, sive superstes eris, <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Her. 13, 164</bibl>. (But <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,031:22:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mil. 22, 58</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 35</bibl>, and similar passages, are to be taken in the usual signif.)—</sense><sense id="n357.9" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To turn out</hi> (this very rare): <cit><quote lang="la">timeo “incertum” hoc quorsum accidat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:5:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 5, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">si secus acciderit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:6:21:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 6, 21, 2</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n357.10" n="3" level="3"> In gram., <hi rend="ital">to belong to</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">plurima huic (verbo) accidunt (i. e. genus, tempora),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:5:41 al" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 5, 41 al.</bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
accieo: <entryFree id="n358" type="hapax" key="acci^e^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-cĭĕo</orth>, <itype>ēre, 2</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, old form for accio, ire, <sense id="n358.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to fetch</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to bring</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ego illum huc acciebo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:3:3:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 3, 3, 61</bibl></cit>; dub. (Ritschl and Fleckeisen: oneratum runcinabo).</sense></entryFree>
accinctus: <entryFree id="n359" type="main" key="accinctus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accinctus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos> of</entryFree>
accingo: <entryFree id="n360" type="main" key="accingo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-cingo</orth>, <itype>nxi, nctum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <sense id="n360.0" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to gird to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">on</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to gird round</hi> or <hi rend="ital">about</hi> (in prose, first after the Aug. per.; <cit><quote lang="la">in poetry, a favorite word with Verg.): lateri ensem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:489" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 489</bibl></cit>; and <hi rend="ital">med.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to gird one's self</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">accingitur ense,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 7, 640</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">quo (ense) fuit accinctus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:6:551" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 6, 551</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">ferro,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:6:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 6, 2</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n360.1" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to arm</hi>, <hi rend="ital">equip</hi>, <hi rend="ital">furnish</hi>, <hi rend="ital">provide</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">facibus pubes accingitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:74" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 74</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">gladiis accincti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 40, 13</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">hence: accinctus miles,</quote> <trans><tr>an armed soldier</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:11:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 11, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ornat Phraaten accingitque (sc. diademate imposito) paternum ad fastigium,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">accinctus gemmis fuigentibus ensis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:3:514" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 3, 514</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n360.2" n="II" level="1"> Fig. </sense><sense id="n360.3" n="A" level="2"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">to endow</hi>, <hi rend="ital">provide;</hi> in medicine: <cit><quote lang="la">magicas accingier artes,</quote> <trans><tr>to have recourse to</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:493" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 493</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n360.4" n="B" level="2"> In part.: accingere se or accingi, <hi rend="ital">to enter upon</hi> or <hi rend="ital">undertake a thing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">girded</hi>, i. e. <hi rend="ital">well prepared</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to prepare one's self</hi>, <hi rend="ital">make one's self ready</hi> (taken from the girding of the flowing robes when in active occupation); constr. <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>, with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in</hi>, <case>dat.</case>, or <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tibi omne est exedendum, accingere,</quote> <trans><tr>make yourself ready</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ter.</author> Ph. 2, 2, 4</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:5:9:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 5, 9, 30</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:1043" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 1043</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">illi se praedae accingunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:210" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 210</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">accingi ad consulatum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 2</bibl></cit>; in Tac. very often actively, <hi rend="ital">to make any one ready</hi> for something: <cit><quote lang="la">turmas peditum ad munia accingere, A. 12, 31: accingi ad ultionem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:H. 4:79" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 4, 79</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in audaciam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:ib. 3:66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 66</bibl></cit> al.; with <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">accingar dicere pugnas Caesaris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 46</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">so: navare operam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:15:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 15, 51</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n360.5" n="b" level="4"> Also in the active form, as <hi rend="ital">v. neutr.</hi> = se accingere: age, anus, accinge ad molas, Pompon. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 469, 28</bibl> (R<bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Com. Rel. p. 235</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">accingunt omnes operi,</quote> <trans><tr>all go vigorously to the work</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:235" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 235</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-cinctus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">well girded.</hi> </sense><sense id="n360.6" n="A" level="2"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: cujus aut familiaris habitus condecentior aut militaris accinctior, Auson. <bibl default="NO"><author>Grat.</author> Act. 27</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n360.7" n="B" level="2"> Fig., <hi rend="ital">ready</hi>, <hi rend="ital">strict</hi> (opp. negligens): <cit><quote lang="la">tam in omnia pariter intenta bonitas et accincta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:30" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 30 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">comitatus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:ib. 20:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 20, 3</bibl></cit>. <cb n="ACCI" /></sense></entryFree>
accino: <entryFree id="n361" type="gloss" key="acci^no"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-cĭno</orth>, <itype>ĕre</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> <etym>cano</etym>, <sense id="n361.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to sing to</hi> any thing, acc. to <bibl default="NO"><author>Diom.</author> p. 425</bibl> P.; cf. accano.</sense></entryFree>
accio: <entryFree id="n362" type="main" key="acci^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-cĭo</orth>, <itype>īvi, ītum, 4</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n362.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to call</hi> or <hi rend="ital">summon</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to fetch</hi> (rare but class.). </sense><sense id="n362.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: cujus vos tumulti causā accicrim, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 484, 7</bibl> (R<bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Trag. Rel. p. 199</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">horriferis accibant vocibus Orcum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:996" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 996</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tu invita mulieres, ego accivero pueros,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:5:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 5, 1, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">13, 48, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:35:141" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 3, 35, 141</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 108" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 108</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:5 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 5 al.</bibl> —</sense><sense id="n362.2" n="II" level="1"> Fig.: <cit><quote lang="la">accire mortem,</quote> <trans><tr>to kill one's self</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:38" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 38 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:4:2:71" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 4, 2, 71</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">scientiam artemque haruspicum accibam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 3</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">accitis quae usquam egregia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:3:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 3, 27</bibl></cit>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">patrios mores funditus everti per accitam lasciviam,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>borrowed</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 14, 20</bibl></cit> (but in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:31:93" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fin. 5, 31, 93</bibl>, the read. acciret is very doubtful; v. Madv. a. h. l.; Klotz reads faceret; B. and K., crearet.).</sense></entryFree>
accipio: <entryFree id="n363" type="main" key="acci^pi^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-cĭpĭo</orth>, <itype>cēpi, ceptum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> (<sense id="n363.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fut. perf.</hi> accepso = accepero, Pac. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 74, 31</bibl>, or R<bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Trag. Rel. 118</bibl>) [capio], <hi rend="ital">to accept.</hi> </sense><sense id="n363.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">to take a person</hi> or <hi rend="ital">thing to</hi> one's self: leno ad se accipiet hominem et aurum, <hi rend="ital">will take the man and his money to himself</hi> (into his house), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:1:1:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Poen. 1, 1, 51</bibl>. </sense><sense id="n363.2" n="a" level="4"> Of things received by the hand, <hi rend="ital">to take</hi>, <hi rend="ital">receive</hi>: cette manus vestras measque accipite, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 85, 1</bibl> (Trag. v. 320 ed. Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">ex tua accepi manu pateram,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Plaut.</author> Amph. 2, 2, 132</bibl></cit>; hence, trop. of the word given, the <hi rend="ital">promise</hi>, with which a grasping of the hand was usually connected: accipe daque fidem, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 6, 1</bibl> (Ann. v. 33 ed. Vahl.; so in the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">pista\ dou=nai kai\ labei=n</foreign>); cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:4:87" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 2, 4, 87</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:150" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 150</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">in Ter. of a person to be protected: hanc (virginem) accepi, acceptam servabo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:1:5:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 1, 5, 62</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 7, 5</bibl>, and <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 6:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 6, 5</bibl>, —</sense><sense id="n363.3" n="b" level="4"> Of things received or taken by different parts of the body: accipite hoc onus in vestros collos, Cato ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 200, 23</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">gremio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:685" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 685</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">oculis aut pectore noctem (i. e. somnum),</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 531</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n363.4" n="c" level="4"> In gen., very freq., </sense><sense id="n363.5" n="(a)" level="5"> as implying action, <hi rend="ital">to take</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to take possession of</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to accept</hi> (Gr. <foreign lang="greek">de/xesqai</foreign>); </sense><sense id="n363.6" n="(b)" level="5"> of something that falls to one's share, <hi rend="ital">to get</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to receive</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be the recipient of</hi> (Gr. <foreign lang="greek">lamba/nein</foreign>).—</sense><sense id="n363.7" n="(a)" level="5"> <hi rend="ital">To take</hi>, <hi rend="ital">accept</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">hanc epistulam accipe a me,</quote> <trans><tr>take this letter from me</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:2:2:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 2, 2, 52</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">4, 2, 26</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:3:4:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ep. 3, 4, 26</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">persuasit aliis, ut pecuniam accipere mallent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:23:82" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 23, 82</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">condicionem pacis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">armis obsidibusque acceptis Crassus profectus est,</quote> <trans><tr>after he had taken into his possession the arms and hostages</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">divitias,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Epam. 4:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Epam. 4, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquid a patre,</quote> <trans><tr>to inherit</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,013:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Timoth. 1, 1</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">accipe et haec, manuum tibi quae monumenta mearum sint,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:486 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 486 al.</bibl></cit>—Hence <hi rend="ital">to receive</hi> or <hi rend="ital">entertain as guest</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec (tellus) fessos placidissima portu accipit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:78" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 78</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Laurentes nymphae, accipite Aenean,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 8, 71</bibl></cit>; 155; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:655 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 655 al.</bibl>—Of admittance to political privileges: <cit><quote lang="la">Nomentani et Pedani in civitatem accepti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 14</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:11:35" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 11, 35</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">magnifice volo summos viros accipere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:2:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 1, 2, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in loco festivo sumus festive accepti,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 19</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,007:1:1:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cist. 1, 1, 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:5:2:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Men. 5, 2, 44</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:1:1:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pers. 1, 1, 32</bibl>, etc.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:5:9:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 5, 9, 52</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:907" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 907</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:16:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 16, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:2:725 al" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 2, 725 al.</bibl>—Hence also ironically, <hi rend="ital">to entertain</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to treat</hi>, <hi rend="ital">deal with</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ego te miseris jam accipiam modis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:4:4:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 4, 4, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">hominem accipiam quibus dictis maeret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:5:1:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Men. 5, 1, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">indignis acceptus modis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:2:1:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 2, 1, 12</bibl></cit>. Perh. also Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 521, 1</bibl>: adeo male me accipiunt decimae, <hi rend="ital">treat</hi> or <hi rend="ital">use me ill</hi>, <hi rend="ital">deal harshly with me;</hi> and <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 240, 8</bibl>: sic, inquam, veteratorem illum vetulum lupum Hannibalem acceptum (Non. explains the latter in a very unusual manner, by <hi rend="ital">deceptum</hi>).— </sense><sense id="n363.8" n="(b)" level="5"> <hi rend="ital">To get</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to receive</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be the recipient of</hi>, Pac. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 74, 31</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:819:909" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 819, 909</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:762:885:1009" default="NO" valid="yes">2, 762, 885, 1009</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ictus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:1048" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 4, 1048</bibl></cit> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:243" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 243</bibl>: vulnera accipiunt tergo): aridior nubes accipit ignem, <hi rend="ital">takes</hi> or <hi rend="ital">catches fire</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:150" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 150</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 48</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">humanitatem iis tribuere debemus, a quibus accepimus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:1:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 1, 1, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecuniam ob rem judicandam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:chapter=38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 1, 38</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">luna lumen solis accipit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 3, 45</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 10, 17</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">praeclarum accepimus a majoribus morem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:10:44" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 10, 44</bibl></cit>: praecepta, Caes. <cb n="ACCI" /> B. G. 2, 6: accepi tuas litteras (in another sense than above), <hi rend="ital">I have received your letter</hi>, <hi rend="ital">it has reached me</hi> (allatae sunt ad me), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:1:9:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 1, 9, 14</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 1, 1</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">10, 1 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">acceptā injuriā ignoscere quam persequi malebant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 9:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 9, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 33</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">calamitatem,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 1, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">detrimenta,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 5, 22</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:21:44 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mur. 21, 44 al.</bibl> So often of dignities and offices: <cit><quote lang="la">provinciam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:2:10:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 2, 10, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">consulatum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:10" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Galliam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:22 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Caes. 22 al.</bibl></cit></sense><sense id="n363.9" n="II" level="1"> In partic. </sense><sense id="n363.10" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To take a thing</hi> by hearing, i. e., </sense><sense id="n363.11" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To hear</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to perceive</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to observe</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to learn</hi> (cf. opp. do = <hi rend="ital">I give</hi> in words, i. e. <hi rend="ital">I say</hi>): hoc simul accipe dictum, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:12:38" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 12, 38</bibl> (Ann. v. 204): quod ego inaudivi, accipite, Pac. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 126, 22</bibl> (R<bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Trag. Rel. p. 81</bibl>): hoc etiam accipe quod dico, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 240, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">carmen auribus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:983" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 983</bibl></cit> (so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:164" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 6, 164</bibl>); 1, 270; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 65</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">voces,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:613" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 613</bibl></cit> (so 6, 171): <cit><quote lang="la">si te aequo animo ferre accipiet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:2:3:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 2, 3, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae gerantur, accipies ex Pollione,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:1:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 1, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 9, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 7</bibl>. —Hence very freq. in the histt., <hi rend="ital">to get</hi> or <hi rend="ital">receive intelligence</hi> of any thing, <hi rend="ital">to learn</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">urbem Romam, sicuti ego accepi, condidere atque habuere initio Trojani,</quote> <trans><tr>as I have learned</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 6:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 6, 1</bibl></cit>, and so al.—</sense><sense id="n363.12" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">To comprehend</hi> or <hi rend="ital">understand any thing communicated</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">haud satis meo corde accepi querelas tuas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:2:2:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. 2, 2, 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">et si quis est, qui haec putet arte accipi posse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:25:114" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 25, 114</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut non solum celeriter acciperet, quae tradebantur, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:1:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Att. 1, 3</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:3:3" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 3, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:9:3 al" default="NO">2, 9, 3 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n363.13" n="3" level="3"> With the accessory idea of judging, <hi rend="ital">to take a thing thus or thus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to interpret</hi> or <hi rend="ital">explain</hi>, usually constr. with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> or <hi rend="ital">in c. acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quibus res sunt minus secundae . . . ad contumeliam omnia accipiunt magis,</quote> <trans><tr>the more unfortunate one is</tr>, <tr>the more inclined is he to regard every thing as an insult</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:4:3:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Ad. 4, 3, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in eam partem accipio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:5:2:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 5, 2, 37</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:10:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 10, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:16:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 16, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:1:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 1, 2, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">non recte accipis,</quote> <trans><tr>you put a wrong construction upon this</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:2:2:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> And. 2, 2, 30</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae sibi quisque facilia factu putat, aequo animo accipit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 3, 2</bibl></cit>.— Hence: accipere aliquid omen, or in omen, <hi rend="ital">to regard a thing as a</hi> (<hi rend="ital">favorable</hi>) <hi rend="ital">omen</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to accept the omen</hi> (cf. <foreign lang="greek">de/xesqai to\n oi)wno/n</foreign>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:46:103" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 46, 103</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 40, 83</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:7:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 7, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:63" default="NO" valid="yes">21, 63</bibl> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:62" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 62</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> A. 1, 28</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:4:12:14 al" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 4, 12, 14 al.</bibl>—Hence <usg type="style">poet.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">accipio agnoscoque deos,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:260" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 12, 260</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:7:620" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 7, 620</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n363.14" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To take a thing upon</hi> one's self, <hi rend="ital">to undertake</hi> (syn. suscipio): <cit><quote lang="la">accipito hanc ad te litem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:5:2:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 5, 2, 23</bibl></cit>: meā causā causam accipite, Ter. Hec. alt. prol. 47; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:7:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 7, 24</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 22</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:20 al" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 20 al.</bibl>—Hence also, </sense><sense id="n363.15" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To bear</hi>, <hi rend="ital">endure</hi>, <hi rend="ital">suffer</hi> any thing disagreeable or troublesome: <cit><quote lang="la">hanccine ego ut contumeliam tam insignem ad me accipiam!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:4:7:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 4, 7, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nil satis firmi video, quamobrem accipere hunc me expediat metum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:2:3:96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 2, 3, 96</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">5, 1, 59</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:4:6:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Eun. 4, 6, 24</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,006:2:1:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ad. 2, 1, 53</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ph. 5, 2, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:19:56" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 19, 56</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">calamitatem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:26" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">injuriam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 11</bibl></cit> al.— </sense><sense id="n363.16" n="D" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To accept a thing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be satisfied with</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to approve</hi>: dos, Pamphile, est decem talenta; <hi rend="ital">Pam.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Accipio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:5:4:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 5, 4, 48</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">accepit condicionem, dein quaestum accipit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 1, 52</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">visa ista ... accipio iisque interdum etiam assentior, nec percipio tamen,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 20, 66</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">preces suas acceptas ab dis immortalibus ominati,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:42:30:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 42, 30, 8</bibl></cit> Drak. Cf. Herz, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:5:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 5, 1</bibl>: “equi te esse feri similem, dico.” Ridemus et ipse Messius: “accipio.” <hi rend="ital">I allow it</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Exactly so</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:5:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 5, 58</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n363.17" n="E" level="2"> In mercant. lang., t. t., <hi rend="ital">to receive</hi> or <hi rend="ital">collect a sum</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pro quo (frumento) cum a Varinio praetore pecuniam accepisset,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fl. 45</bibl></cit>; hence <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">acceptum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the receipt</hi>, and in account-books <hi rend="ital">the credit side</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in acceptum referre alicui,</quote> <trans><tr>to carry over to the credit side</tr>, <tr>to place to one's credit</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:36:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 1, 36, 57</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,003:chapter=2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Com. 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 2, 16</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Caec. 6, 17</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 1, 234</bibl> (opp. datum or expensum).—Hence also trop., <hi rend="ital">to owe</hi> or <hi rend="ital">be indebted to one</hi>, in a good or a bad sense: <cit><quote lang="la">ut esset nemo qui non mihi vitam suam, liberos, remp. referret acceptam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:2:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 2, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnia mala, quae postea vidimus, uni accepta referemus Antonio,</quote> <trans><tr>ascribe</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 22</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:8:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 8, 58</bibl>; id. B. C, 3, 57: Acceptum <pb n="18" /> <cb n="ACCL" /> refero versibus, esse nocens, <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Trist. 2, 10</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n363.18" n="F" level="1"> In the gram m., <hi rend="ital">to take a word</hi> or <hi rend="ital">phrase thus or thus</hi>, to <hi rend="ital">explain a word</hi> in any manner: <cit><quote lang="la">adversus interdum promiscue accipitur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 207</bibl></cit> P. al.—(Syn. nanciscor and adipiscor: he to whom something is given, <hi rend="ital">accipit;</hi> he who gets by a fortunate occurrence, <hi rend="ital">nanciscitur;</hi> he who obtains it by exertion, <hi rend="ital">adipiscitur.</hi> “<hi rend="ital">Sumimus</hi> ipsi: <hi rend="ital">accipimus</hi> ab alio,” Vel. Long. p. 2243 P.—“Inter <hi rend="ital">tenere</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sumere</hi> et <hi rend="ital">accipere</hi> hoc interest, quod <hi rend="ital">tenemus</hi> quae sunt in nostra potestate: <hi rend="ital">sumimus</hi> posita: <hi rend="ital">accipimus</hi> data,” <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Diff. 1</bibl>).—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">acceptus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">welcome</hi>, <hi rend="ital">agreeable</hi>, <hi rend="ital">acceptable</hi> (syn. gratus. <hi rend="ital">Acceptus</hi> is related to <hi rend="ital">gratus</hi>, as the effect to the cause; he who is <hi rend="ital">gratus</hi>, i. e. dear, is on that account <hi rend="ital">acceptus</hi>, welcome, acceptable; <cit><quote lang="la">hence the usual position: gratus atque acceptus).—First, of persons: essetne apud te is servus acceptissimus?</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Plaut.</author> Cap. 3, 5, 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">plebi acceptus erat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 13</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">acceptus erat in oculis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,011:18:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 1 Reg. 18, 5</bibl></cit>.— <cit><quote lang="la">Of things: dis et hominibus est acceptum quod, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 3:16:5" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 3, 16, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod vero approbaris. id gratum acceptumque habendum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:15:45" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 15, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">munus eorum gratum acceptumque esse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Hann. 7:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Hann. 7, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quorum mihi dona accepta et grata habeo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:2:7:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 2, 7, 56</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rem populo Romano gratam acceptamque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:13:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Phil. 13, 50</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">tempore accepto exaudivi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,008:6:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 2 Cor. 6, 2</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:4:4:96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 4, 4, 96</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:6:13" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 6, 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:6:45 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 6, 45 al.</bibl>—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>, see above.—<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi> <orth extent="full" lang="la">accepte</orth> does not occur.</sense></entryFree>
accipenser: <entryFree id="n364" type="main" key="accipenser"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accipenser</orth>, v. acipenser.</entryFree>
accipiter: <entryFree id="n365" type="main" key="acci^pi^ter"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accĭpĭter</orth>, <itype>tris</itype> (earlier also tĕris, <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 695</bibl> P.), <gen>m.</gen> (<gen>f.</gen> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:1006" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 1006</bibl>) [com. deriv. from accipio; see 2. acceptor; but cf. <foreign lang="greek">w)ku/pteros</foreign>, swift-winged], a general name for birds of prey, esp. those of the falcon kind, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:10:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 10, 8, 9, § 21</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Ter.</author> Ph. 2, 2, 16</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:107" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 107</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:19" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 19</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 16, 50 al.</bibl>—<sense id="n365.0" n="B" level="2"> In partic. </sense><sense id="n365.1" n="1" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">The common hawk</hi>, Falco Palumbarius, Linn.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:37:17 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 37, 17 sq.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:5:605 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 5, 605 sq.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:8:4:6" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 8, 4, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:3:8:4 al" default="NO">3, 8, 4 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sacer, because auguries were taken from it,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:721" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 721</bibl></cit> (cf. Hom. Od. 15, 525 sq.).—</sense><sense id="n365.2" n="2" level="3"> <hi rend="ital">The sparrowhawk</hi>, Falco Nisus, Linn., used in fowling; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:14:216" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 14, 216</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n365.3" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, of a rapacious man: <cit><quote lang="la">labes populi, pecuniai accipiter,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:3:3:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 3, 3, 5</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
accipitrina: <entryFree id="n366" type="hapax" key="acci^pi^tri_na"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accĭpĭtrīna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>accipiter</etym>, <sense id="n366.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">hawkweed</hi>, hieracium, Linn.; <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 30</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
accipitro: <entryFree id="n367" type="hapax" key="acci^pi^tro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accĭpĭtro</orth>, <itype>āre, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, used by Laevius for lacerare, <sense id="n367.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to tear</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to lacerate</hi>, ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:19:7:11" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 19, 7, 11</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
accisus: <entryFree id="n368" type="main" key="acci_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accīsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos> of accīdo.</entryFree>
accitio: <entryFree id="n369" type="main" key="acci_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accītĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>accio</etym>, <sense id="n369.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a calling</hi> or <hi rend="ital">summoning</hi> (late Lat.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 4, p. 134</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
accitus: <entryFree id="n370" type="main" key="acci_tus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accītus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> of accio.</entryFree>

<entryFree id="n371" type="main" key="acci_tus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accītus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> (only in <sense id="n371.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">abl. sing.</hi>) [accio], <hi rend="ital">a summoning to a place</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a summons</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a call</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">magistratus accitu istius evocantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:28:section=68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 28, § 68</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">accitu cari genitoris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:677" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 677</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
accius: <entryFree id="n372" type="main" key="Acci^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Accĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, v. Attius.</entryFree>
acclamatio: <entryFree id="n373" type="main" key="accla_ma_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">acclāmātĭo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adc.</orth>), <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>acclamo</etym>, <sense id="n373.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a calling to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an exclamation</hi>, <hi rend="ital">shout.</hi> </sense><sense id="n373.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">acuta atque attenuata nimis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 3, 12, 21</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">the calling of the shepherd,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:7:3:26" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 7, 3, 26</bibl></cit>; so in <number>plur.</number>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:6:2:14" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 6, 2, 14</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n373.2" n="II" level="1"> In partic. </sense><sense id="n373.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A cry of disapprobation</hi> (so esp. in the time of the republic): <cit><quote lang="la">ei contigit non modo ut adclamatione, sed ut convicio et maledictis impediretur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:2:3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 2, 3, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">2, 1, 2</bibl>; quanto jam levior est adclamatio, C. Rabir. 18; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:83:339" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 83, 339</bibl> etc.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=dom.:23 al" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Dom. 23 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n373.4" n="B" level="2"> On the contrary, esp. later, <hi rend="ital">a shout of approbation</hi> (e. g. on the appearance of a person honored by the people), <hi rend="ital">a huzza</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">adclamationes multitudinis assentatione immodica pudorem operantis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:31:15:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 31, 15, 2</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:79" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 79</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:58" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Aug. 58</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=otho:6" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Oth. 6</bibl> (made by the voice; while <hi rend="ital">plausus</hi> is made with the hands, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:3:3" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 8, 3, 3</bibl>).—</sense><sense id="n373.5" n="C" level="2"> Rhetor. a figure of speech = exclamatio, <foreign lang="greek">e)pifw/nhma</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">exclamation</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:5:11" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 8, 5, 11</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acclamito: <entryFree id="n374" type="spur" key="accla_mi^to"><orth extent="full" lang="la">acclāmĭto</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, a false read. in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:3:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 3, 2, 3</bibl>, for occlamitat.</entryFree>
acclamo: <entryFree id="n375" type="main" key="accla_mo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-clāmo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adc.</orth>), <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos>, <sense id="n375.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to raise a cry at</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to shout at</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to exclaim</hi> (in a <cb n="ACCO" /> friendly or hostile manner), with and without the <hi rend="ital">dat.;</hi> also with the <case>acc.</case> of <hi rend="ital">the thing</hi> called. </sense><sense id="n375.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To shout at</hi> in a hostile sense, <hi rend="ital">to disapprove</hi> or <hi rend="ital">blame by shouting</hi> (so partic. in the time of the republic): <cit><quote lang="la">non metuo, ne mihi adclametis,</quote> <trans><tr>cry out against</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:73:256" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 73, 256</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Muren. 8</bibl>; id. Piso, 65; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:chapter=48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 48</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:chapter=28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Caecin. 28</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 47:11" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 47, 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=gal.:20 al" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Galb. 20 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">hostis omnibus, qui adclamassent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 20</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:2:4:4" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 2, 4, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:70 al" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 70 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n375.2" n="II" level="1"> After the Aug. period, <hi rend="ital">to cry at with approbation</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to shout applause</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to approve with loud cries</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to applaud</hi>, <hi rend="ital">huzza</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">populus et miles Neroni Othoni adclamavit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:78" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 78</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:7" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 7</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">27</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=dom.:13 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Dom. 13 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">prosequentibus cunctis servatorem liberatoremque adclamantibus,</quote> <trans><tr>they applaud him with loud acclamations as their saviour and deliverer</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 34, 50 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:44 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 44 al.</bibl>—<hi rend="ital">Impers.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ei adclamatum est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:4:9:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 4, 9, 18</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
acclaro: <entryFree id="n376" type="hapax" key="accla_ro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-clāro</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adc.</orth>), <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n376.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to make clear</hi> or <hi rend="ital">evident</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to show</hi> or <hi rend="ital">make known;</hi> in the lang. of the augurs: <cit><quote lang="la">uti tu signa nobis certa adclarassis (i. e. adclaraveris),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 18 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
acclinis: <entryFree id="n377" type="main" key="accli_nis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">acclīnis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> (also adc-) [ad-CLINO], <sense id="n377.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">leaning on</hi> or <hi rend="ital">against something</hi>, <hi rend="ital">inclined to</hi> or <hi rend="ital">toward</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg> and in post-Aug. prose); constr. with <case>dat.</case> </sense><sense id="n377.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">corpusque levabat arboris adclinis trunco,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:10:834" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 10, 834</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:15:737" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 15, 737</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Silv. 5, 3, 36 al.</bibl>—In prose, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 15, 16, § 39</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:28:4" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 28, 4</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">crates inter se acclines,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:12:15:1" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 12, 15, 1</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n377.2" n="B" level="2"> Esp. of localities, <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 14, 8</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">29, 5</bibl>.— </sense><sense id="n377.3" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">inclined to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">disposed to</hi> (= inclinatus, propensus): <cit><quote lang="la">acclinis falsis animus meliora recusat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 2, 6</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
acclino: <entryFree id="n378" type="main" key="accli_no"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-clīno</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n378.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to lean on</hi> or <hi rend="ital">against something</hi> (not before the Aug. period; mostly <usg type="style">poet.</usg>). </sense><sense id="n378.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">se acclinavit in illum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:5:72" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 5, 72</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">latus leoni,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Silv. 4, 2, 51</bibl></cit>.—Most freq. in <hi rend="ital">part. pass.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">acclinatus: colla acclinata,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:10:268" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 10, 268</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">terrae acclinatus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:14:666" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 14, 666</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">castra tumulo sunt acclinata,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:44:3:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 44, 3, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">maria terris,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Silv. 5, 4, 5</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n378.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, with se, <hi rend="ital">to incline to a thing</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad causam senatus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:4:48:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 4, 48, 9</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
acclivis: <entryFree id="n379" type="main" key="accli_vis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-clīvis</orth>, <itype>e, also</itype> (but much less freq.) <orth extent="full" lang="la">-vus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>ad + clivus</etym>, <sense id="n379.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">up hill</hi>, <hi rend="ital">mounting upwards</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ascending</hi>, <hi rend="ital">steep</hi>: stadium, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 4, 11</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ea viae pars valde acclivis est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:3:1:2:section=4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Q. Fr. 3, 1, 2, § 4</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">leniter acclivis aditus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:29 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 29 al.</bibl></cit>: <hi rend="ital">acclivus</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 19</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acclivitas: <entryFree id="n380" type="main" key="accli_vi^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">acclīvĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>acclivis</etym>, <sense id="n380.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an ascending direction</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an acclivity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ascent</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pari acclivitate collis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 18</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:2:4:10" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 2, 4, 10</bibl>.—Concr. of the <hi rend="ital">rising place</hi> itself, <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 14, 2, 13</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acclivus: <entryFree id="n381" type="main" key="accli_vus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">acclīvus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, v. acclivis.</entryFree>
acco: <entryFree id="n382" type="main" key="Acco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Acco</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n382.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a chieftain of the Senones</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:6:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 6, 4</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">44 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
accognosco: <entryFree id="n383" type="main" key="accognosco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-cognosco</orth>, <itype>ĕre, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n383.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to know</hi> or <hi rend="ital">recognize perfectly</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> Fragm. 69</bibl> Burm.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> ad Ux. 2, 6</bibl>; adv. Marc. 4, 20 al.</sense></entryFree>
accola: <entryFree id="n384" type="main" key="acco^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accŏla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <sense id="n384.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">c.</hi> [accolo], <hi rend="ital">a dweller by</hi> or <hi rend="ital">near a place</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a neighbor</hi> (<hi rend="ital">incola</hi>, one who dwells in a place): <cit><quote lang="la">optati cives, populares, incolae, accolae, advenae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:3:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 3, 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pastor accola ejus loci,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:7:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 7, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:37:53" default="NO" valid="yes">37, 53</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:68" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 68</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:729 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 729 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">accolae Cereris,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>dwellers at her temple</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:50:section=111" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 50, § 111</bibl></cit>.—In <itype>Tacitus</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, of the tributary streams of the Tiber: Tiberim accolis fluviis orbatum, <hi rend="ital">the neighboring rivers</hi>, A. 1, 79. (The Vulg. uses this word in the sense of <hi rend="ital">incola</hi>: accola in terra, Psa. 104, 23; Act. 7, 6: terrae, Lev. 18, 27.)</sense></entryFree>
