accolo: <entryFree id="n385" type="main" key="acco^lo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-cŏlo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adc.</orth>), <itype>cŏlui, cultum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n385.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to dwell by</hi> or <hi rend="ital">near</hi>, constr. with <case>acc.</case> or <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> </sense><sense id="n385.1" n="(a)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: Histrum fluvium, Naev ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:45:152" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 45, 152</bibl> (R<bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Trag. Rel. p. 14</bibl>): arcem, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 357, 14</bibl> (<bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> p. 202</bibl>): illum locum, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:6:18" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 6, 18 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">viam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28:13:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 28, 13, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Macedoniam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:39:46:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 39, 46, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Pontum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Nilum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:288" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 288</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">Rhenum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:1:51" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 1, 51</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nives Haemi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:1:390" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 1, 390</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Capitolī saxum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:9:448 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 9, 448 al.</bibl></cit>; hence, <hi rend="ital">pass.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">fluvius crebris oppidis accolitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 1, 30, § 9</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n385.2" n="(b)" level="5"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">vicine Apollo, qui aedibus Propinquus nostris adcolis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:2:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 2, 1, 4</bibl></cit> (the <case>dat.</case> aedibus belongs to propinquus, not to adcolis, as <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 1203</bibl> P. seems to have construed).—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg>: accolere vitem, <hi rend="ital">to be</hi> <cb n="ACCR" /> <hi rend="ital">a cultivating neighbor of it</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:62:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 62, 55</bibl> dub. (Müller reads coluere.)</sense></entryFree>
accommodate: <entryFree id="n386" type="main" key="accommo^da_te"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accommŏdāte</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. accommodo, <sense id="n386.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">P. a. fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
accommodatio: <entryFree id="n387" type="main" key="accommo^da_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accommŏdātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>accommodo</etym>, <sense id="n387.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the fitting</hi> or <hi rend="ital">adjusting of one thing to another.</hi> </sense><sense id="n387.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">a. verborum et sententiarum ad inventionem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:1:7:9" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Inv. 1, 7, 9</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n387.2" n="II" level="1"> Esp., <hi rend="ital">the adapting of one's feeling</hi> or <hi rend="ital">will to another's</hi>, <hi rend="ital">compliance</hi>, <hi rend="ital">complaisance</hi>, <hi rend="ital">indulgence</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex liberalitate atque accommodatione magistratuum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:82:section=189" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 82, § 189</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
accommodatus: <entryFree id="n388" type="main" key="accommo^da_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accommŏdātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos> of</entryFree>
accommodo: <entryFree id="n389" type="main" key="accommo^do"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-commŏdo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum</itype> (better, adc.), <itype>1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n389.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to fit</hi> or <hi rend="ital">adapt one thing to another</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to lay</hi>, <hi rend="ital">put</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">hang on</hi> (in good prose, esp. in Cic., very freq.), constr. with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi>, <case>dat.</case>, or <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi> </sense><sense id="n389.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">coronam sibi ad caput,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:61:250" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 61, 250</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">clupeum ad dorsum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:3:2:93" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 3, 2, 93</bibl></cit>: gladium dextrae, Lucil. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:21:48" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 21, 48</bibl>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">hastam dextrae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:5:146" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 5, 146</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">calauticam capiti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,062:Or. in Clod. 5" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fragm. Or. in Clod. 5</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">lateri ensem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:393" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 393</bibl></cit>; <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">insignia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:2:21:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 2, 21, 5</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n389.2" n="B" level="2"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">to prepare for any use</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Arabus lapis dentifriciis adcommodatur crematus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:153" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 21, 41, § 153</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n389.3" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to adjust</hi> or <hi rend="ital">adapt to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to accommodate to</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">meum consilium adcommodabo ad tuum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 9, 7</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:10:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 10, 7</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">12, 32</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:3:2 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 3, 2 al.</bibl>—Hence, with se, <hi rend="ital">to adapt one's self to another's opinion</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wishes</hi>, etc., <hi rend="ital">to conform to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to comply with</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnes qui probari volunt, ad eorum qui audiunt arbitrium et nutum totos se fingunt et adcommodant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:8:24" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 8, 24</bibl></cit>: alicui de aliqua re, <hi rend="ital">to be compliant to one in any thing</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">peto a te ... ut ei de habitatione adcommodes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:13:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 13, 2</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n389.4" n="B" level="2"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">to bring a person</hi> or <hi rend="ital">thing to something</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to apply</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">testes ad crimen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:18:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 1, 18, 55</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vim ad eloquentiam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:chapter=7" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">curam pratis, etc.,</quote> <trans><tr>to apply</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:12:7" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 12, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nonnullam operam his studiis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:10:15" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 1, 10, 15</bibl></cit>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">1, 8, 19: verba alicui (equival. to dare),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:6:1:27" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 6, 1, 27</bibl></cit>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">11, 1, 39 al.: intentionem his,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:2:5:2 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 2, 5, 2 al.</bibl></cit>— Hence, with se (in a more general sense than above), <hi rend="ital">to apply</hi> or <hi rend="ital">devote one's self to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to undertake</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">se ad rem publicam et ad res magnas gerendas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:21" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 21</bibl></cit>; of property, <hi rend="ital">to lend it to one for use</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">si quid iste suorum aedilibus adcommodavit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 57</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">accommŏdātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">fitted</hi> or <hi rend="ital">adapted to</hi>, <hi rend="ital">suitable</hi>, <hi rend="ital">conformable</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">appropriate to</hi> (only in prose; in poetry, <hi rend="ital">accommodus</hi> is used), with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> or <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">puppes ad magnitudinem fluctuum adcommodatae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:3:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 3, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">oratio ad persuadendum adcommodata,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 1, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae mihi intelligis esse adcommodata,</quote> <trans><tr>conformable to my interest</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 3, 3</bibl></cit>. —<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">oratio contionibus concitatis adcommodatior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 1</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:3:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 3, 13</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nobis accommodatior,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:4:1:5" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 4, 1, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:8" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 8</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">exemplum temporibus suis adcommodatissimum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,062:Corn. 7" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fragm. Corn. 7</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:13:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 13, 3, 6, § 26</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:5:19:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 5, 19, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:10:63 al" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 10, 63 al.</bibl>—<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">accommŏ-dāte</orth>, <hi rend="ital">fitly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">suitably</hi>, <hi rend="ital">agreeably</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">dicere quam maxime adc. ad veritatem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:33:149" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 33, 149</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:33:117" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 33, 117</bibl>.— <hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:5:9:24" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 5, 9, 24</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
accommodus: <entryFree id="n390" type="main" key="accommo^dus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-commŏdus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adc.</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n390.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fit</hi>, <hi rend="ital">suitable</hi> (vox Verg. and <usg type="style">poet.</usg> for <hi rend="ital">adcommodatus</hi>); with <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">valles adcommoda fraudi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:522" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 522</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">membra bellis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:4:4:65" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 4, 4, 65</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nox fraudi,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Theb. 10, 192</bibl></cit>.— Also in late prose, Cod. Th. 15, 1, 41; <bibl default="NO"><author>Pall.</author> Jul. 8, 2</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Veg.</author> 4, 2, 12 al.</bibl>—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sup.</hi>, and <pos>adv.</pos> not found.</sense></entryFree>
accongero: <entryFree id="n391" type="hapax" key="acconge^ro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-congĕro</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adc.</orth>), <itype>essi, estum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, <sense id="n391.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to bear</hi> or <hi rend="ital">bring to</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ego huic dona adcongessi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:1:2:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 1, 2, 17</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
accorporo: <entryFree id="n392" type="main" key="accorpo^ro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-corpŏro</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adc.</orth>), <itype>āre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>ad + corpus</etym>: aliquid alicui, <sense id="n392.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to incorporate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to fit</hi> or <hi rend="ital">join to</hi> (late Lat.), <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 16, 8, 11</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Sol.</author> 37</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
accredo: <entryFree id="n393" type="main" key="accre_do"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-crēdo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adc.</orth>), <itype>dĭdi, dĭtum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> (<sense id="n393.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pres. sub.</hi> adcredŭas, <bibl default="NO"><author>Plaut.</author> Asin. 5, 2, 4</bibl>), <hi rend="ital">to yield one's belief to</hi> another, i. e. <hi rend="ital">to believe unconditionally</hi> (rare). </sense><sense id="n393.1" n="(a)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">dat.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quisnam istuc adcredat tibi?</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Plaut.</author> Asin. 3, 3, 37</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">neque mi posthac quidquam adcreduas,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 5, 2, 4</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">tibi nos,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 15, 25</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n393.2" n="(b)" level="5"> <hi rend="ital">Aliquid</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">facile hoc,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:856" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 856</bibl></cit>. <pb n="19" /> <cb n="ACCU" /> —</sense><sense id="n393.3" n="(g)" level="5"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: vix adcredens, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:6:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 6, 2, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">primo non accredidit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,014:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Dat. 3</bibl></cit>. 4.</sense></entryFree>
accrementum: <entryFree id="n394" type="spur" key="accre_mentum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accrēmentum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, a false read. in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 9, 1, 2</bibl>, for nutrimentum.</entryFree>
accresco: <entryFree id="n395" type="main" key="accresco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-cresco</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adc.</orth>), <itype>ēvi, ētum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos>, <sense id="n395.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to grow</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to become larger by growth</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to increase.</hi> </sense><sense id="n395.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">nobis jam paulatim adcrescere puer incipiat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:2:1" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 2, 1</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">adcrescens imperator,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Amm.</author> 27, 6, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">eruca,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:32:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 32, 37</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 35, 41</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">flumen subito,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:2:31:97" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Inv. 2, 31, 97</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">nondum adcrescente unda,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">caespes jam pectori usque adcreverat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 19</bibl></cit>.—<mood>Part.</mood>: <cit><quote lang="la">adcretus, in pass. sense,</quote> <trans><tr>wrapped up</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:32:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 32, 37</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n395.2" n="b" level="4"> Of abstract subjects: <cit><quote lang="la">valetudo decrescit, adcrescit labor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,008:2:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Curc. 2, 1, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">amicitiam, quae incepta a parvis cum aetate adcrevit simul,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:3:3:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 3, 3, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dolores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,025:21:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Att. 21, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">invidia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:6:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 6, 26</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">magnum facinus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ben. 1:10:4" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ben. 1, 10, 4</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n395.3" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, in gen. </sense><sense id="n395.4" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To be added to by way of increase</hi> or <hi rend="ital">augmentation</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to be joined</hi> or <hi rend="ital">annexed to</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">si decem jugera (agri) alluvione adcreverint,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:19:1:13:section=14" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 19, 1, 13, § 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">veteribus negotiis nova adcrescunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:2:8:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 2, 8, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sibi adcrescere putat, quod cuique adstruatur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:62:8" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Pan. 62, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">trimetris adcrescere jussit nomen iambeis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:252" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> A. P. 252</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum dictis factisque omnibus vana accresceret fides,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:54:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 54, 2</bibl></cit>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n395.5" n="B" level="2"> Jurid. t. t., <hi rend="ital">to fall to one</hi>, as an increase of his property, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1251,001:2:199" default="NO"><author>Gai.</author> 2, 199</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:12:4:12 al" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 12, 4, 12 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">jus adcrescendi,</quote> <trans><tr>the right of increase</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1251,001:2:126" default="NO"><author>Gai.</author> 2, 126</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:7:2:1:section=3 al" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 7, 2, 1, § 3 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
accretio: <entryFree id="n396" type="hapax" key="accre_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accrētĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>accresco</etym>, <sense id="n396.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an increasing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">increment</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">lunam accretione et deminutione luminis ... significantem dies,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:28:68" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 28, 68</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
accua: <entryFree id="n397" type="main" key="Accu^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Accŭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n397.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town of Apulia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:24:20:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 24, 20, 8</bibl>; dub., <hi rend="ital">v.</hi> Weissenb. a. h. l.</sense></entryFree>
accubatio: <entryFree id="n398" type="main" key="accu^ba_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accŭbātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>accubo</etym>, a rare collat. form of accubitio, <sense id="n398.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a lying</hi>, <hi rend="ital">reclining</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:35:128" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 35, 128</bibl>, acc. to the MSS.</sense></entryFree>
accubitalia: <entryFree id="n399" type="hapax" key="accu^bi^ta_li^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accŭbĭtālĭa</orth>, <itype>ĭum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, sc. stragula, <sense id="n399.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the coverings spread over the tablecouches</hi>, Trebell. <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> 14</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
accubitatio: <entryFree id="n400" type="main" key="accu^bi^ta_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accŭbĭtātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>accubito</etym>, <sense id="n400.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a reclining</hi>, <hi rend="ital">lying at</hi> the table, <bibl default="NO"><author>Spart.</author> Ver. 5</bibl>; cf. accubitio.</sense></entryFree>
accubitio: <entryFree id="n401" type="main" key="accu^bi^ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accŭbĭtĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>accubo</etym>. <sense id="n401.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A lying</hi> or <hi rend="ital">reclining</hi>, esp. at meals (in the Rom. manner, on the triclinium or accubitum): <cit><quote lang="la">accubitio epularis amicorum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> de Sen. 13, 45</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 193, 30</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:34:94" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 34, 94</bibl> (but in Off. 1, 35, 128, the MSS. give accubatio).—</sense><sense id="n401.1" n="II" level="1"> Concr., <hi rend="ital">a couch</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Lampr.</author> Sev. 34</bibl>; cf. accubitatio.</sense></entryFree>
accubito: <entryFree id="n402" type="main" key="accu^bi^to"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accŭbĭto</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, = accubo, Eccl.</entryFree>
accubitorius: <entryFree id="n403" type="main" key="accu^bi^to_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accŭbĭtōrĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>accubo</etym>, <sense id="n403.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to reclining</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">vestimenta,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 30</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
accubitum: <entryFree id="n404" type="main" key="accu^bi^tum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accŭbĭtum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n404.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a couch for a large number of guests to recline on at meals</hi> (while the triclinium contained only three seats), <bibl default="NO"><author>Lampr.</author> Heliog. 19, 25 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
accubitus: <entryFree id="n405" type="main" key="accu^bi^tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accŭbĭtus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = accubitio. <sense id="n405.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A reclining at table</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,003:1:110" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Ach. 1, 110</bibl> (quoted by <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 863</bibl> P.); <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Theb. 1, 714</bibl>; and perh. also Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 20, 11, 19</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n405.1" n="II" level="1"> Per meton., <hi rend="ital">a couch</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,031:1:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Cant. 1, 11</bibl>; <hi rend="ital">a place on a couch</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,003:14:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Luc. 14, 7</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
accubo: <entryFree id="n406" type="main" key="accu^bo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-cŭbo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adc.</orth>), <itype>āre, 1</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos>, t. t. (the forms accubui and accubitum belong to accumbo), <sense id="n406.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to lie near</hi> or <hi rend="ital">by</hi> a thing. </sense><sense id="n406.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen., constr. with <case>dat.</case> or <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quoi bini castodes semper accubant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:2:2:57" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 2, 2, 57</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Furiarum maxima juxta accubat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:606" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 606</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">accubantes effodiunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 35, 6, 19, § 37</bibl></cit>.—Rarely with <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">lectum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 5, p. 160</bibl></cit>.—Of things: <cit><quote lang="la">nigrum nemus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:334" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 3, 334</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cadus (vini),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:12:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 12, 18</bibl></cit>.—Also of places (for adjacere): <cit><quote lang="la">theatrum Tarpeio monti accubans,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:44" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 44</bibl></cit>.—Esp. </sense><sense id="n406.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To recline at table</hi> (in the Rom. manner): <cit><quote lang="la">accubantes in conviviis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:5:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 2, 5, 10</bibl></cit>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">in convivio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,016:3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Pel. 3, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:23" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 3, 23</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">morem apud majores hunc epularum fuisse, ut deinceps, qui accubarent, canerent ad tibiam, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:2:3" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 2, 3</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">regulus accubans epulari coepit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:41:2:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 41, 2, 12</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">so,</quote> <trans><tr>absol</tr>.,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:2:3:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Stich. 2, 3, 53</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,003:4:5:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Eun. 4, 5, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:49 al" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 49 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum aliquo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:4:72" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 2, 4, 72</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">infra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:39:43:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 39, 43, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">contra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:98" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 98</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n406.3" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To lie with</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:1:1:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 1, 1, 39</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">3, 3, 50</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=vesp.:21" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Vesp. 21</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
accubuo: <entryFree id="n407" type="hapax" key="accu^bu^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-cŭbŭo</orth> (better, accubio, Lachm. <cb n="ACCU" /> ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:679" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 679 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl>), <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>accubo</etym>, <sense id="n407.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">lying near</hi>, a word formed by Plautus to answer to assiduo (fr. sedeo), Truc. 2, 4, 68.</sense></entryFree>
accudo: <entryFree id="n408" type="hapax" key="accu_do"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-cūdo</orth>, <itype>ĕre, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, lit. <sense id="n408.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to strike</hi> or <hi rend="ital">stamp upon</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to coin</hi> (of gold; cf. cudo); hence, metaph., <hi rend="ital">to coin further</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to add to a sum of money</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">tris minas accudere etiam possum, et triginta sient,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:2:3:96" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Merc. 2, 3, 96</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
accumbo: <entryFree id="n409" type="main" key="accumbo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-cumbo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adc.</orth>), <itype>cŭbui, cŭbĭtum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos>, <sense id="n409.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to lay one's self down at</hi> a place; and hence, <hi rend="ital">to lie</hi> somewhere. </sense><sense id="n409.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen. (so very rare): <cit><quote lang="la">in via,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:1:4:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 1, 4, 13</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">of one swimming: summis in undis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Manil.</author> 5, 429</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n409.2" n="II" level="1"> In part. </sense><sense id="n409.3" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">To recline at table</hi>, in the manner in which the Romans (and finally even the Roman women, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:2:1:2" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 2, 1, 2</bibl>) reclined, after luxury and effeminacy had become prevalent. While they extended the lower part of the body upon the couch (triclinium, lectus triclinaris), they supported the upper part by the left arm upon a cushion (or upon the bosom of the one nearest; <cit><quote lang="la">hence, in sinu accumbere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:39:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 39, 43</bibl></cit>; cf. <foreign lang="greek">a)nakei=sqai</foreign> = <foreign lang="greek">ei)=nai e)n tw=| ko/lpw| tino/s</foreign>, Ev. Ioh. 13, 23), the right hand only being used in taking food: <cit><quote lang="la">hoc age, adcumbe,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:5:1:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 5, 1, 15</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:1:3:150" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 1, 3, 150</bibl>, etc.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 31</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:chapter=35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mur. 35</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 28, 18</bibl>; <hi rend="ital">c. acc.</hi>: mensam, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 415, 26</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0043,001:Sat. 13" default="NO"><author>Lucil.</author> Sat. 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0043,001:511:16" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 511, 16</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">cotidianis epulis in robore,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:chapter=74" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mur. 74</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in convivio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:chapter=66" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 1, 66</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in epulo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,023:chapter=12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Vatin. 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">epulis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:79" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 79</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">tecum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:5:2:75" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 5, 2, 75</bibl></cit>; <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,034:chapter=17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Deiot. 17</bibl>.—Since three persons usually reclined upon such a couch (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:chapter=27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 27</bibl>), these expressions arose: in summo (or superiorem, also supra), medium and imum (or infra) adcumbere; and the series began on the left side, since they lay supported by the left arm. The whole arrangement is explained by the following figure: <figure /> Among the three lecti, the lectus medius was the most honorable; and on each lectus, the locus medius was more honorable than the summus; and this had the preference to the imus or ultimus. The consul or other magistrate usually sat as imus of the lectus medius (fig. <hi rend="ital">no.</hi> 6), in order that, by his position at the corner, he might be able, without trouble, to attend to any official business that might occur. The place <hi rend="ital">no.</hi> 7 seems, for a similar reason, to have been taken by the host. See on this subject Salmas. <bibl default="NO"><author>Sol.</author> p. 886</bibl>; Smith's Antiq.; Becker's Gall. 3, p. 206 sq. (2d ed.); and Orell. excurs. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:8:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 8, 20</bibl>. This statement explains the passages in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:5:1:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Pers. 5, 1, 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:1:1:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Most. 1, 1, 42</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:3:2:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Stich. 3, 2, 37</bibl>, etc.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 1, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 9, 26</bibl>; Sall. Fragm. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 1, 702</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:8:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 8, 20</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n409.4" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">In mal. part.</hi> (rarely), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:5:2:73" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 5, 2, 73</bibl>; Men. 3, 2, 11; 5, 9, 82.</sense></entryFree>
accumulate: <entryFree id="n410" type="main" key="accu^mu^la_te"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accŭmŭlāte</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adc.</orth>), <pos>adv.</pos>, v. accumulo <sense id="n410.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
accumulatio: <entryFree id="n411" type="hapax" key="accu^mu^la_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accŭmŭlātĭo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adc.</orth>), <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>accumulo</etym>, <sense id="n411.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a heaping up</hi>, only as t. t. in the lang. of gardening, of <hi rend="ital">the heaping up of earth round the roots of plants</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:246" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 26, 39, § 246</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
accumulator: <entryFree id="n412" type="hapax" key="accu^mu^la_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accŭmŭlātor</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adc.</orth>), <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n412.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one who heaps up</hi> or <hi rend="ital">accumulates</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">opum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:3:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 3, 30</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
accumulo: <entryFree id="n413" type="main" key="accu^mu^lo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-cŭmŭlo</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adc.</orth>), <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>cumulus</etym>, <sense id="n413.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to add to a heap</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to heap up</hi>, <hi rend="ital">accumulate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to augment by heaping up</hi> (mostly poetical). </sense><sense id="n413.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> </sense><sense id="n413.2" n="A" level="2"> In gen.: <cit><quote lang="la">ventorum flatu congeriem arenae accumulantium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 1, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">confertos acervatim mors accumulabat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:1263" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 1263</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>, <cb n="ACCU" /> of heaping up money: auget, addit, adcumulat, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:22:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Agr. 2, 22, 59</bibl>. (The syn. <hi rend="ital">augere</hi> and <hi rend="ital">addere</hi> are used of any object, although still small, in extent or number, after the increase; but <hi rend="ital">adcumulare</hi> only when it becomes of considerable magnitude; hence the climax in the passage quoted from Cic.)—</sense><sense id="n413.3" n="B" level="2"> Esp., botan. t. t., <hi rend="ital">to heap up earth round the roots of plants</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to trench up</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:139" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 19, 31, § 139</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:295" default="NO" valid="yes">18, 29, 71, § 295</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:19:83 al" default="NO" valid="yes">19, 5, 26, § 83 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n413.4" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to heap</hi>, <hi rend="ital">add</hi>, <hi rend="ital">increase</hi>: virtutes generis meis moribus, Epitaph of a Scipio in Inscr. Orell. <hi rend="ital">no.</hi> 554: <cit><quote lang="la">caedem caede,</quote> <trans><tr>to heap murder upon murder</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:71" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 71</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquem donis,</quote> <trans><tr>to heap offerings upon one</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:6:886" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 6, 886</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">honorem alicui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:2:122" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 2, 122</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">curas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:15:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 15, 70</bibl></cit>.—<usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: quod ait (Vergilius) <hi rend="ital">sidera lambit</hi> (A. 3, 574), vacanter hoc etiam accumulavit et inaniter, <hi rend="ital">has piled up words</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:17:10:16" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 17, 10, 16</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">accŭmŭlāte</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">abundantly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">copiously</hi> (very rare): <cit><quote lang="la">id prolixe accumulateque fecit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fl. 89</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">accumulate largiri,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 1, 17 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">prolixe accumulateque pollicetur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 10, p. 212</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
accurate: <entryFree id="n414" type="main" key="accu_ra_te"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accūrāte</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. <itype>accuro</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos></entryFree>
accuratio: <entryFree id="n415" type="main" key="accu_ra_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accūrātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>accuro</etym>, <sense id="n415.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">accuracy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">exactness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">carefulness</hi> (very rare): <cit><quote lang="la">mira in inveniendis componendisque rebus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:67:238" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 67, 238</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad omnem accurationem = accuratissime,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Veg.</author> 1, 56, 35</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
accuratus: <entryFree id="n416" type="main" key="accu_ra_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accūrātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, from</entryFree>
accuro: <entryFree id="n417" type="main" key="accu_ro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-cūro</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adc.</orth>), <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> (arch. accurassis = accuraveris, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:4:1:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 4, 1, 29</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:3:1:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pers. 3, 1, 65</bibl>), <sense id="n417.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to take care of</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to do a thing with care.</hi> </sense><sense id="n417.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen. (in Plaut. and Ter. very often; more rare in the class. per., partic. in the <hi rend="ital">verb. fin.;</hi> while the <pos>P. a.</pos> occurs very often in Cic., see below). </sense><sense id="n417.2" n="(a)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">acc.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">prandium alicui,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Plaut.</author> Mer. 1, 3, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quod facto est opus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:3:3:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cas. 3, 3, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rem sobrie aut frugaliter,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,014:4:1:1 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Pers. 4, 1, 1 al.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">melius adcurantur, quae consilio geruntur, quam quae sine consilio administrantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:1:34:58" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Inv. 1, 34, 58</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">virtus et cultus humanus sub tecto adcurantur,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fr. in Col. 12 praef.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">barbam,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Lampr.</author> Heliog. 31</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n417.3" n="(b)" level="5"> <usg type="style"><hi rend="ital">Absol.</hi></usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">ergo adcures: properato opus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:3:1:210" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Mil. 3, 1, 210</bibl></cit>, v. Ritschl a. h. l.—</sense><sense id="n417.4" n="(g)" level="5"> With <hi rend="ital">ut</hi> or <hi rend="ital">ne</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">omnes bonos bonasque adcurare addecet, suspicionem et culpam ut ab se segregent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:1:2:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 1, 2, 42</bibl></cit>; so with <hi rend="ital">ut</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,001:3:2:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> And. 3, 2, 14</bibl>; with <hi rend="ital">ne</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:5:1:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Hec. 5, 1, 12</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n417.5" n="II" level="1"> Esp.: <cit><quote lang="la">adcurare aliquem,</quote> <trans><tr>to treat one carefully</tr>, <tr>regale a guest</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:5:1:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ep. 5, 1, 55</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">accūrātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">prepared with care</hi>, <hi rend="ital">careful</hi>, <hi rend="ital">studied</hi>, <hi rend="ital">elaborate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">exact</hi> (never of persons, for which <hi rend="ital">diligens</hi> is used; <cit><quote lang="la">syn.: meditatus, exquisitus, elaboratus, politus): adcurata malitia,</quote> <trans><tr>a studied artifice</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:2:5:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 2, 5, 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adcuratae et meditatae commentationes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:60:257" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 60, 257</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adcuratius et exquisitius dicendi genus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:82:283" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 82, 283</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">adcuratissima diligentia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:7:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 7, 3</bibl></cit> al: <cit><quote lang="la">adcuratum habere = adcurare,</quote> <trans><tr>to take care</tr>, <tr>be at pains</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Plaut.</author> Bac. 3, 6, 21</bibl></cit>. —<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">accūrāte</orth>, <hi rend="ital">carefully</hi>, <hi rend="ital">nicely</hi>, <hi rend="ital">exactly</hi> (syn.: <cit><quote lang="la">diligenter, studiose, exquisite),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:16:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 16, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Parad. 1, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:22 al" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 22 al.</bibl>—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:8:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 8, 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:6:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 6, 22</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> B. Alex. 12</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fam. 5, 17</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,006:4:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Lys. 4, 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
accurro: <entryFree id="n418" type="main" key="accurro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-curro</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adc.</orth>), <itype>cŭcurri and curri, cursum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos>, <sense id="n418.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to run to a</hi> place, <hi rend="ital">to come to by running</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to hasten to.</hi> </sense><sense id="n418.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> constr. <hi rend="ital">absol.</hi>, with <hi rend="ital">ad</hi> and <hi rend="ital">in</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">expeditus facito ut sis, si inclamāro ut accurras,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:2:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 2, 20</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">12, 18</bibl> (accucurrisse); <cit><quote lang="la">13, 48: cupide ad praetorem accurrit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:5:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 5, 3</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 22</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 3, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 106:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 106, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">in Tusculanum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:15:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 15, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad gemitum collabentis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in castra,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Caes.</author> B. Alex. 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in auxilium accucurrerunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:58" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 58</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad visendum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:34" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ner. 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">auxilio suis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 101:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 101, 10</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Impers.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">accurritur ab universis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:1:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 1, 21</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n418.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, of ideas: <cit><quote lang="la">istae imagines ita nobis dicto audientes sunt, ut simul atque velimus accurrant,</quote> <trans><tr>come up</tr>, <tr>present themselves</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:2:67:138" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 2, 67, 138</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
accursus: <entryFree id="n419" type="main" key="accursus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accursus</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">adc.</orth>), <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>accurro</etym>, <sense id="n419.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a running</hi> or <hi rend="ital">coming to</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Remi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:2:3:72" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 2, 3, 72</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">comitum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:6:511" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 6, 511</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">populi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:4:41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 4, 41</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">subitus militum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:6:8:6" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 6, 8, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tot provinciarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:25 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 4, 25 al.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">civium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Hipp. 894" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Hipp. 894</bibl></cit>. <pb n="20" /> <cb n="ACCU" /></sense></entryFree>
accusabilis: <entryFree id="n420" type="hapax" key="accu_sa_bi^lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accūsābĭlis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>accuso</etym>, <sense id="n420.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">blameworthy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">reprehensible</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">turpitudo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:4:35:75" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 4, 35, 75</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
accusatio: <entryFree id="n421" type="main" key="accu_sa_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accūsātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n421.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">complaint</hi>, <hi rend="ital">accusation</hi>, <hi rend="ital">indictment.</hi> </sense><sense id="n421.1" n="I" level="1"> In abstr.: <cit><quote lang="la">ratio judiciorum ex accusatione et defensione constat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:2:14" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 2, 14</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">comparare and constituere accusationem,</quote> <trans><tr>to bring in</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:chapter=1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">intentare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:6:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 6, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">capessere,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 52</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">exercere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> H. 2, 10</bibl></cit>: factitare, <hi rend="ital">to pursue</hi> or <hi rend="ital">urge</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=34" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 34</bibl>: accusatione desistere, <hi rend="ital">to desist from</hi>, <hi rend="ital">give up</hi>, id. Fragm. Corn. ap. Ascon.; <cit><quote lang="la">later, demittere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:28:2" default="NO"><author>Aur. Vict.</author> 28, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">accusationi respondere,</quote> <trans><tr>to answer</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:chapter=3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 3</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n421.2" n="II" level="1"> In concr., <hi rend="ital">the bill of indictment</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the action</hi> or <hi rend="ital">suit</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">in accusationis septem libris,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>in the Orations against Verres</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:29:103" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 29, 103</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:110" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 7, 30, 31, § 110</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
accusativus: <entryFree id="n422" type="main" key="accu_sa_ti_vus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accūsātīvus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype> <etym>id., prop. belonging to an accusation, hence</etym>, in gramm. with or without casus, <sense id="n422.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the accusative case</hi>, as if the defendant in a suit, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 8:section=67" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 8, § 67</bibl> Müll. (in the prec. §: casus accusandi); <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:7:9:10" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 7, 9, 10</bibl>, and all the later writers.—Hence, praepositiones accusativae, i. e. <hi rend="ital">those joined with the accusative</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 1, 28 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
accusator: <entryFree id="n423" type="main" key="accu_sa_tor"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accūsātor</orth>, <itype>ōris</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, orig. <sense id="n423.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">one who calls another to account;</hi> hence, transferred to public life, <hi rend="ital">an accuser</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a plaintiff</hi>, esp. in a state-offence (while <hi rend="ital">petitor</hi> signifies a plaintiff in private causes; yet accusator is often used for every kind of accuser, and then includes the petitor, v. accuso <hi rend="ital">no.</hi> II. A.). </sense><sense id="n423.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen. (very freq.): <cit><quote lang="la">accusatorem pro omni actore et petitore appello,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,038:32:110" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Part. Or. 32, 110</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">possumus petitoris personam capere, accusatoris deponere?</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Quint. 13 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:6:1:36" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 6, 1, 36</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">accusatores multos esse in civitate utile est, ut metu contineatur audacia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:chapter=20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Am. 20</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">acres atque acerbi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:chapter=36" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Brut. 36</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vehemens et molestus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 34</bibl></cit> <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">graves, voluntarii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:3:20:47" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Leg. 3, 20, 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">firmus verusque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,004:9:29 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Div. in Caecil. 9, 29 al.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">eundem accusatorem capitis sui ac judicem esse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:32:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 32, 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ita ille imprudens ipse suus fuit accusator,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,006:4:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Lys. 4, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">graviter eos accusat quod, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:16:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 16, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">accusatores tui,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:23:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Act. 23, 35</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">25, 18 al.</bibl>— </sense><sense id="n423.2" n="II" level="1"> Esp., in silv. age, <hi rend="ital">an informer</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a denouncer</hi> (= delator): <cit><quote lang="la">accusatorum denuntiationes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=aug.:66" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Aug. 66</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:1:161" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 1, 161</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
accusatorie: <entryFree id="n424" type="main" key="accu_sa_to_ri^e"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accūsātōrĭe</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. accusatorius.</entryFree>
accusatorius: <entryFree id="n425" type="main" key="accu_sa_to_ri^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accūsātōrĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>accusator</etym>, <sense id="n425.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to an accuser</hi>, <hi rend="ital">accusatory</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">lex,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,014:chapter=5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Mur. 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jus et mos,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Flacc. 6, 14</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">artificium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:17:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 17, 49</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">animus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:4:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Clu. 4, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vox,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:45:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 45, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">spiritus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 61</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vita,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:7:3" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 12, 7, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">libelli,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:48:5:17:section=1 al" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 48, 5, 17, § 1 al.</bibl></cit>—<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">accūsātōrĭe</orth>, <hi rend="ital">in the manner of an accuser</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:2:72:section=176" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 2, 72, § 176</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 3, 70, § 164</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:40:12:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 40, 12, 6</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
accusatrix: <entryFree id="n426" type="main" key="accu_sa_trix"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accūsātrix</orth>, <itype>īcis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n426.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">she who makes accusation against any one</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a female accuser</hi> (v. accuso <hi rend="ital">no.</hi> I.): <cit><quote lang="la">tu mi accusatrix ades,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:3:1:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 3, 1, 10</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:10:67" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 10, 67</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> Op. Min. 102</bibl> Lind.</sense></entryFree>
accusito: <entryFree id="n427" type="hapax" key="accu_si^to"><orth extent="full" lang="la">accūsĭto</orth>, <itype>āre, 1</itype>, <sense id="n427.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. freq.</hi> [accuso], <hi rend="ital">to accuse</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nil erit quod deorum ullum accusites,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,013:3:2:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Most. 3, 2, 23</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
accuso: <entryFree id="n428" type="main" key="accu_so"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ac-cūso</orth> (also with ss; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Cassiod.</author> 2283</bibl> P.), <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>fr. causa; cf. cludo with claudo</etym>, orig. = ad causam provocare, <sense id="n428.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to call one to account</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to make complaint against</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to reproach</hi>, <hi rend="ital">blame.</hi> </sense><sense id="n428.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen., of persons: <cit><quote lang="la">si id non me accusas, tu ipse objurgandus es,</quote> <trans><tr>if you do not call me to account for it</tr>, <tr>you yourself deserve to be reprimanded</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:1:2:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 1, 2, 59</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quid me accusas?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:1:3:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> As. 1, 3, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">meretricem hanc primum adeundam censeo, oremus, accusemus gravius, denique minitemur,</quote> <trans><tr>we must entreat</tr>, <tr>severely chide</tr>, <tr>and finally threaten her</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:4:4:94 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 4, 4, 94 sq.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ambo accusandi,</quote> <trans><tr>you both deserve reproach</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,002:1:1:67" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Heaut. 1, 1, 67</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cotidie accusabam,</quote> <trans><tr>I daily took him to task</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 1, 50</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">me accusas cum hunc casum tam graviter feram,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:3:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 3, 13</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 1, 1</bibl> Manut.: <cit><quote lang="la">me tibi excuso in eo ipso, in quo te accuso,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:2:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Q. Fr. 2, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut me accusare de epistularum neglegentia possis,</quote> <trans><tr>that you may blame me for my tardiness in writing</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 1, 6</bibl></cit>. —Also metaph. of things, <hi rend="ital">to blame</hi>, <hi rend="ital">find fault with</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">alicujus desperationem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:6:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 6, 1</bibl></cit>: inertiam adolescentium, id. de <cb n="ACER" /> Or. 1, 58 (cf. incusare, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 4, 42</bibl>); <cit><quote lang="la">hence also: culpam alicujus,</quote> <trans><tr>to lay the fault on one</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:4:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Planc. 4, 9</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:38:80" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sest. 38, 80</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,033:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Lig. 1, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:12:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cael. 12, 29</bibl>.—Hence,</sense><sense id="n428.2" n="II" level="1"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n428.3" n="A" level="2"> Transferred to civil life, <hi rend="ital">to call one to account publicly</hi> (ad causam publicam, or publice dicendam provocare), <hi rend="ital">to accuse</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to inform against</hi>, <hi rend="ital">arraign</hi>, <hi rend="ital">indict</hi> (while incusare means to involve or entangle one in a cause); t. t. in Roman judicial lang.; constr. with <hi rend="ital">aliquem alicujus rei</hi> (like <foreign lang="greek">kathgorei=n</foreign>, cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> 1187</bibl> P.): <cit><quote lang="la">accusant ii, qui in fortunas hujus invaserunt, causam dicit is, cui nihil reliquerunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:chapter=5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Am. 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">numquam, si se ambitu commaculasset, ambitus alterum accusaret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,024:chapter=7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cael. 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne quis ante actarum rerum accusaretur,</quote> <trans><tr>that no one should be called to account for previous offences</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Thras. 3:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Thras. 3, 2</bibl></cit>; Milt. 1, 7. Other rarer constructions are: <hi rend="ital">aliquem aliquid</hi> (only with <hi rend="ital">id</hi>, <hi rend="ital">illud</hi>, <hi rend="ital">quod</hi>), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:1:2:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Trin. 1, 2, 59</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Ter.</author> Ph. 5, 8, 21</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">aliquo crimine,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:chapter=16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 1, 16</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Milt. 8</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,006:3:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Lys. 3, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,015:1 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ep. 1 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">de pecuniis repetundis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,010:41:114" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Clu. 41, 114</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">de veneficiis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:32:90" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Rosc. Am. 32, 90</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">inter sicarios,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 32</bibl></cit>; cf. Zumpt, § 446; Rudd. 2, 165 sq.; 169, note 4.—The punishment that is implied in the accusation is put in <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">capitis,</quote> <trans><tr>to accuse one of a capital crime</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,004:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Paus. 2, 6</bibl></cit>; cf. Zumpt, § 447. —</sense><sense id="n428.4" n="B" level="2"> Casus accusandi, <hi rend="ital">the fourth case</hi> in grammar, <hi rend="ital">the accusative case</hi>, Var. L. L. 8, § 66 Müll.; v. accusativus.</sense></entryFree>
ace: <entryFree id="n429" type="main" key="Ace_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Acē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <foreign lang="greek">*)/akh</foreign>, <sense id="n429.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town in Galilee</hi>, afterwards called Ptolemais or Acca, now <hi rend="ital">St. Jean d'Acre</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,014:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Dat. 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:5:75" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 5, 19, 17, § 75</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acedior: <entryFree id="n430" type="greek" key="a^ce_di^or"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcēdĭor</orth>, <itype>āri, 1</itype>, <pos>v. dep.</pos> <etym><foreign lang="greek">a)khdi/a</foreign></etym>, <sense id="n430.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to be morose</hi>, <hi rend="ital">peevish</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Sir. 6, 26</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">22, 6</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acentetus: <entryFree id="n431" type="greek" key="a^cente_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcentētus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ke/nthtos</foreign>, <sense id="n431.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">without points</hi> or <hi rend="ital">spots</hi>: calix, Fronto de fer. Als. 3.—<hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcentēta</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ke/nthta</foreign>, used of crystals, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 2, 10, § 28</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aceo: <entryFree id="n432" type="main" key="a^ce^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcĕo</orth>, <itype>ui, 2</itype>, <pos>v. n.</pos> <etym>v. 2. acer</etym>, <sense id="n432.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to be sour.</hi> </sense><sense id="n432.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg> (of wine): <cit><quote lang="la">vinum, quod neque aceat neque muceat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0022,001:148" default="NO"><author>Cato</author> R. R. 148</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n432.2" n="II" level="1"> Fig., <hi rend="ital">to be disagreeable</hi> (late Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">mentio pectori acet,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Ep. 7, 6</bibl></cit> <hi rend="ital">a med.</hi></sense></entryFree>
acephalus: <entryFree id="n433" type="greek" key="a^ce^pha^lus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcĕphălus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ke/falos.</foreign> <sense id="n433.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Without head</hi>, <hi rend="ital">without chief</hi> or <hi rend="ital">leader.</hi>— <hi rend="ital">Subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăcĕphăli</orth>, <hi rend="ital">a sect of heretics</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Or. 8, 5, 66</bibl>; cf. 5, 39, 39 sq.—</sense><sense id="n433.1" n="II" level="1"> In prosody, of a hexameter which begins with a short syllable (e. g. <foreign lang="greek">e)peidh/</foreign>), Vel. Long. p. 2219 P.</sense></entryFree>
acer: <entryFree id="n434" type="main" key="a^cer1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcer</orth>, <itype>ĕris</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>kindred with Germ. Ahorn</etym> (<gen>f.</gen> Serv. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 698</bibl> P.), <sense id="n434.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the maple-tree</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:66 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 15, 26, § 66 sq.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n434.1" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">the wood of the maple-tree</hi>, <hi rend="ital">maplewood</hi>, used, on account of its hardness and firmness, for writing-tablets, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:33:146" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 33, 11, 52, § 146</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:1:11:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 1, 11, 28</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n435" type="main" key="a_cer2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ācer</orth>, <itype>cris, cre</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> (<gen>m.</gen> acris, Enn.; <gen>f.</gen> acer, Naev. and Enn.; acrus, a um, Pall.; Veg.; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> 63</bibl> and 93 P.) [cf. <foreign lang="greek">a)ki/s, a)kw/n, a/kmh/, a)/kros, w)ku/s, o)cu/s</foreign>; Sanscr. acan = dart, acus = swift; Germ. Ecke; Engl. edge, to egg; and with change of quantity, ăcus, acuo, ăceo, ăcies, ăcerbus], <sense id="n435.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">sharp</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pointed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">piercing</hi>, and the like. </sense><sense id="n435.1" n="I" level="1"> Prop., of the senses and things affecting them, <hi rend="ital">sharp</hi>, <hi rend="ital">dazzling</hi>, <hi rend="ital">stinging</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pungent</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fine</hi>, <hi rend="ital">piercing</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">praestans valetudine, viribus, formā, acerrimis integerrimisque sensibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:15:45" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 15, 45</bibl></cit>. So, </sense><sense id="n435.2" n="a" level="4"> Of the sight: <cit><quote lang="la">acerrimus sensus videndi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:87:357" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 87, 357</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">acres oculi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:chapter=27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Planc. 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">splendor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:304" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 304</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quidam colores ruboris acerrimi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Q. N. 1:14 al" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Q. N. 1, 14 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n435.3" n="b" level="4"> Of the hearing: <cit><quote lang="la">voce increpet acri?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:953" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 953</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aurium mensura, quod est acrius judicium et certius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">acrem flammae sonitum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:4:409" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 4, 409</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">acri tibiā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:12:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 12, 1</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n435.4" n="c" level="4"> Of smell, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:122" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 122</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">exstinctum lumen acri nidore offendit nares,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:792" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 6, 792</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1216" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 1216</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">unguentis minus diu delectemur summa et acerrima suavitate conditis, quam his moderatis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:3:25:99" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 3, 25, 99</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">odor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:17:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 12, 17, 40</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n435.5" n="d" level="4"> Of taste: ut vitet acria, ut est sinapi, cepa, allium, Var. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 201, 13</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">acres humores,</quote> <trans><tr>sharp juices</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:23" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lactuca innatat acri stomacho,</quote> <trans><tr>an acid stomach</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:4:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 4, 59</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 2, 8, 7</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">dulcibus cibis acres acutosque miscere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:7:3 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 7, 3 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n435.6" n="e" level="4"> Of sensation in its widest extent: aestatem<cb n="ACER" />  auctumnus sequitur, post acer hiems fit, <hi rend="ital">sharp</hi>, <hi rend="ital">severe</hi>, Enn. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 647</bibl> P. (Ann. v. 406 ed. Vahl.—cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:261" default="NO" valid="yes">4, 261</bibl>); and so Hor.: solvitur acris hiems, C. 1. 4, 1. —</sense><sense id="n435.7" n="B" level="2"> Of the internal states of the human system, <hi rend="ital">violent</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sharp</hi>, <hi rend="ital">severe</hi>, <hi rend="ital">gnawing</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">fames, Naev. ap. Prisc. l. l. (B. Punic. p. 18 ed. Vahl.): somnus, Enn. ap. Prisc. l. l. (Ann. v. 369): morbus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:5:2:119" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 5, 2, 119</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dolor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:650" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 650</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sitis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:3:77 al" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 1, 3, 77 al.</bibl></cit></sense><sense id="n435.8" n="II" level="1"> Of the states of mind: <hi rend="ital">violent</hi>, <hi rend="ital">vehement</hi>, <hi rend="ital">passionate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">consuming</hi>: mors amici subigit, quae mihi est senium multo acerrimum, Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 2, 22</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">acri ira percitus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:400" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 400</bibl></cit>: cf. 3, 312; <cit><quote lang="la">6, 754 (on the contrary, 5, 1194: iras acerbas): acres curae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:463" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 463</bibl></cit>, and Var. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 241</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">luctus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 87</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dolor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:291" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 291</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">metus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:1211" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 1211</bibl></cit>;
