<bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:362" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 362</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">amor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:2:6:15" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 2, 6, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">acrior ad Venerem cupido,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:6:5 al" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 6, 5 al.</bibl></cit> (Among unpleasant sensations, <hi rend="ital">acer</hi> designates a <hi rend="ital">piercing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wounding by sharpness;</hi> but <hi rend="ital">acerbus</hi> the rough, harsh, repugnant, repulsive.)—</sense><sense id="n435.9" n="B" level="2"> Applied to the intellectual qualities, <hi rend="ital">subtle</hi>, <hi rend="ital">acute</hi>, <hi rend="ital">penetrating</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sagacious</hi>, <hi rend="ital">shrewd</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">acrem irritat virtutem animi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 70</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">acri judicio perpende,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:1041" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 1041</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">memoria,</quote> <trans><tr>strong</tr>, <tr>retentive</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:87" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 2, 87</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vir acri ingenio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:chapter=5" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 5</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:20 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sest. 20 al.</bibl> —</sense><sense id="n435.10" n="C" level="2"> Applied to moral qualities. </sense><sense id="n435.11" n="1" level="3"> In a good sense, <hi rend="ital">active</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ardent</hi>, <hi rend="ital">eager</hi>, <hi rend="ital">spirited</hi>, <hi rend="ital">brave</hi>, <hi rend="ital">zealous</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">milites,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:2:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 2, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">civis acerrimus,</quote> <trans><tr>an ardent patriot</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:10:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 10, 28</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">defensor,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">studio acriore esse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">jam tum acer curas venientem extendit in annum rusticus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:405 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 405 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n435.12" n="2" level="3"> In a bad sense, <hi rend="ital">violent</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hasty</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hot</hi>, <hi rend="ital">passionate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fierce</hi>, <hi rend="ital">severe</hi> (very freq.): <cit><quote lang="la">uxor acerrima,</quote> <trans><tr>enraged</tr>, <tr>angry</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:4:4:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Merc. 4, 4, 56</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Ter.</author> Ph. 2, 1, 32</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">dominos acres,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 63</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Tim. 3:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Tim. 3, 5</bibl>; cf. Bremi <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,018:11:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Eum. 11, 1</bibl>. Also, of animals, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:421" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 421</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:860" default="NO" valid="yes">5, 860</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:4:156" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 4, 156</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:12:6" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 12, 6</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">2, 31</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,018:11:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Eum. 11, 1</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n435.13" n="D" level="2"> Of abstract things (mostly <usg type="style">poet.</usg>), <bibl default="NO"><author>Ter.</author> Ph. 2, 2, 32</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">egestas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:65" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 65</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">poenas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:72" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 6, 72</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">impetus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:128" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 128</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:392" default="NO" valid="yes">392</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">acerrimum bellum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,026:chapter=6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Balb. 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nox acerrima atque acerbissima,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,015:chapter=18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sull. 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">acrius supplicium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 1, 1</bibl></cit>; in Quint.: acres syllabae, <hi rend="ital">which proceed from short to long</hi>, 9, 4.—Acer is constr. with <case>abl.</case>, and also (esp. in the histt. of the <hi rend="ital">silv.</hi> age) with <hi rend="ital">gen.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:1:13" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 1, 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:2:5 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 2, 5 al.</bibl>; cf. Ramsh. § 107, 6 note. With <hi rend="ital">in</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:8:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 8, 15</bibl>; with <hi rend="ital">inf.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:3:338" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 3, 338</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ācrĭter</orth>, <hi rend="ital">sharply</hi>, <hi rend="ital">strongly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">vehemently</hi>, <hi rend="ital">eagerly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">zealously</hi>, etc., in all the signif. of the adj., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,007:1:1:110" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cist. 1, 1, 110</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:3:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ps. 1, 3, 39</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:783" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 783</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:30 al" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 30 al.</bibl>—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 54</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:1147" default="NO" valid="yes">5, 1147</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:3:92" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 3, 92</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:6:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 6, 45</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">13, 3</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fl. 11</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:10:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 10, 28</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">15, 4</bibl>.—Also, <orth extent="full" lang="la">ācre</orth>, Sall. Fragm. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 132, 25</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 10, 32</bibl>; and perh. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:4:34" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 4, 34</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aceratus: <entryFree id="n436" type="main" key="a^ce^ra_tus" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcĕrātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>acus, ĕris</etym>, <sense id="n436.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">mingled with chaff</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">lutum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=20" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 20</bibl></cit>, and 187 Müll.; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 445, 14</bibl>.</sense><sense id="n436.1" n="2" level="3"> † <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcĕrătus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)ke/ratos</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">without horns</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">cochleae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:30:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 30, 6, 15, § 46</bibl></cit> dub. (acc. to others, ăcērătae = <foreign lang="greek">a)kh/ratoi</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">complete</hi>).</sense></entryFree>
acerbe: <entryFree id="n437" type="main" key="a^cerbe"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcerbe</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. acerbus <sense id="n437.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
acerbitas: <entryFree id="n438" type="main" key="a^cerbi^tas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcerbĭtas</orth>, <itype>ātis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>acerbus</etym>, <sense id="n438.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">sharpness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sourness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">harshness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">the harsh taste of fruits.</hi> </sense><sense id="n438.1" n="I" level="1"> Prop.: <cit><quote lang="la">fructus non laetos et uberes, sed magna acerbitate permixtos tulissem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:38:92" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Planc. 38, 92</bibl></cit>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n438.2" n="II" level="1"> Fig., <hi rend="ital">sharpness.</hi> </sense><sense id="n438.3" n="A" level="2"> Of moral qualities, <hi rend="ital">harshness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">severity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rigor</hi>, <hi rend="ital">moroseness</hi> (opp. comitas, lenitas, and the like): <cit><quote lang="la">severitatem probo, acerbitatem nullo modo,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> de Sen. 18</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">acerbitas morum immanitasque naturae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,035:12:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Phil. 12, 11</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,058:1:1:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Q. Fr. 1, 1, 13</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:12" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 12</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:44" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ner. 44</bibl>; cf. Brem. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Dion. 6:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Dion. 6, 5</bibl>.—Also <hi rend="ital">satirical scverity</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">acerbitas et abunde salis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:10:1:94" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 10, 1, 94</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:96:117" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 96, 117</bibl>.—Also <hi rend="ital">violence</hi>, <hi rend="ital">anger</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">dissensio sine acerbitate,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:25" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 25</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:23:87" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Lael. 23, 87</bibl>.—And <hi rend="ital">hatred</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">nomen vestrum odio atque acerbitati scitote nationibus exteris futurum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:30" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 30</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n438.4" n="B" level="2"> Of one's lot or fortune, <hi rend="ital">grief</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sorrow</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pain</hi>, <hi rend="ital">anguish</hi>, <hi rend="ital">affliction</hi>, and the like: <cit><quote lang="la">acerbitas summi luctūs,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:5:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 5, 16</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lacrimas, quas tu in meis acerbitatibus plurimas effudisti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:42:101" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Planc. 42, 101</bibl></cit>: omnes acerbitates, omnes dolores cruciatusque perferre, <pb n="21" /> <cb n="ACER" /> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:4:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 4, 1</bibl>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,022:chapter=38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Sest. 38</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:9:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 9, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,007:6 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Alc. 6 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
acerbitudo: <entryFree id="n439" type="hapax" key="a^cerbi^tu_do"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcerbĭtūdo</orth>, <itype>ĭnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, = acerbitas, acc. to <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:13:3" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 13, 3</bibl>.</entryFree>
acerbo: <entryFree id="n440" type="main" key="a^cerbo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcerbo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>id.</etym> (vox Vergil.). <sense id="n440.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To make harsh</hi> or <hi rend="ital">bitter</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to embitter;</hi> lit. and trop. (very rare): <cit><quote lang="la">gaudia,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:12:75" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 12, 75</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mortem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:6:655" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 6, 655</bibl></cit>.— Hence in an extended sense, </sense><sense id="n440.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">To augment</hi> or <hi rend="ital">aggravate any thing disagreeable</hi> (cf. acuo): <cit><quote lang="la">formidine crimen acerbat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:11:407" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 11, 407</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nefas Eteoclis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:3:214" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 3, 214</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
acerbus: <entryFree id="n441" type="main" key="a^cerbus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcerbus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>fr. 2. acer, like <hi rend="ital">superbus</hi> fr. <hi rend="ital">super</hi>, yet the short ă should be noticed</etym>, <sense id="n441.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">harsh to the taste</hi>, of every object which has an astringent effect upon the tongue (opp. <hi rend="ital">suavis</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:661 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 661 sq.</bibl>). </sense><sense id="n441.1" n="I" level="1"> Prop.: <cit><quote lang="la">Neptuni corpus acerbum,</quote> <trans><tr>bitter</tr>, <tr>briny</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:472" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 472</bibl></cit>; and esp. of unripe fruit, <hi rend="ital">sharp</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sour</hi>, <hi rend="ital">harsh</hi>, and the like: <cit><quote lang="la">uva primo est peracerba gustatu, deinde maturata dulcescit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> de Sen. 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">saporum genera tredecim reperiuntur: acer, acutus, acerbus, acidus, salsus, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:15:27:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 15, 27, 32</bibl></cit>; and since the harshness of fruit is always a sign of immaturity, so Varro, Cicero, Pliny, et al. use acerbus as a syn. for crudus, immaturus, <hi rend="ital">unripe</hi>, <hi rend="ital">crude</hi>, lit. and trop.: nondum matura uva est, nolo acerbam sumere, Phaed. 4, 2, 4; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:2:14:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Am. 2, 14, 24</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">and trop.: impolitae res et acerbae si erunt relictae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,025:chapter=14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Prov. Cons. 14</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:13:2" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 13, 2</bibl>.—Hence: virgo acerba, <hi rend="ital">not yet marriageable</hi>, Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 247, 15</bibl>; and esp. <usg type="style">poet.</usg> (opp. to virgo matura, v. maturus): funus acerbum, as a translation of the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">qa/vatos a)/wros</foreign> (Eur. Orest. 1030), Auct. Or. pro Dom. 16: <cit><quote lang="la">ante diem edere partus acerbos,</quote> <trans><tr>premature</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,007:4:647" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> F. 4, 647</bibl></cit>. —</sense><sense id="n441.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg> </sense><sense id="n441.3" n="(a)" level="5"> to sounds, <hi rend="ital">harsh</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hoarse</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rough</hi>, <hi rend="ital">shrill</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">serrae stridentis acerbum horrorem, Lucr, 2, 410: vox acerbissima,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Auct. Her.</author> 4, 47</bibl></cit>; </sense><sense id="n441.4" n="(b)" level="5"> to feeling, <hi rend="ital">sharp</hi>, <hi rend="ital">keen</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">frigus,</quote> <trans><tr>bitter</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 17, 53</bibl></cit>.</sense><sense id="n441.5" n="II" level="1"> Fig. </sense><sense id="n441.6" n="A" level="2"> Of men: <hi rend="ital">Rough</hi>, <hi rend="ital">coarse</hi>, <hi rend="ital">repulsive</hi>, <hi rend="ital">morose</hi>, <hi rend="ital">violent</hi>, <hi rend="ital">hard</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rigorous</hi>, <hi rend="ital">severe</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">melius de quibusdam acerbos inimicos mereri quam eos amicos, qui dulces videantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:chapter=24" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Lael. 24</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">posse enim asotos ex Aristippi, acerbos e Zenonis schola exire,</quote> <trans><tr>for there may go forth sensualists from the school of Aristippus</tr>, <tr>crabbed fellows from that of Zeno</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:31" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 3, 31</bibl></cit> (cf. acriculus): <cit><quote lang="la">acerbissimi feneratores,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:6:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Att. 6, 1</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">so of adversaries or enemies,</quote> <trans><tr>violent</tr>, <tr>furious</tr>, <tr>bitter</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:1:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 1, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">acerbissimus hostis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:4:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 4, 6 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:3:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 3, 8</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">acerbus odisti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:3:85" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 3, 85</bibl></cit> K. & <cit><quote lang="la">H.: quid messes uris acerba tuas?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:1:2:98 al" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 1, 2, 98 al.</bibl></cit> —</sense><sense id="n441.7" n="B" level="2"> Of things, <hi rend="ital">harsh</hi>, <hi rend="ital">heavy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">disagreeable</hi>, <hi rend="ital">grievous</hi>, <hi rend="ital">troublesome</hi>, <hi rend="ital">bitter</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sad</hi> (very often, esp. in Cic.): <cit><quote lang="la">ut acerbum est, pro benefactis cum mali messem metas!</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:5:2:52" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ep. 5, 2, 52</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:3:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 3, 1, 1</bibl>; Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 72, 29</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">in rebus acerbis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 54</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">acerbissimum supplicium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:4:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Cat. 4, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">acerbissima vexatio,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">acerba memoria temporis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:chapter=41" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Planc. 41</bibl></cit>: acerbissimā morte affectus, Serv. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:4:12:2 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 4, 12, 2 al.</bibl>—Hence acerbum funus (diff. from above), <hi rend="ital">a bitter</hi>, <hi rend="ital">painful death</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:1:1:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 1, 1, 35</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">acerbum funus filiae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:3:3:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> As. 3, 3, 5</bibl></cit>, and so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,005:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Cim. 4</bibl>: vita ejus fuit secura et mors acerba, <hi rend="ital">afflicting</hi>, <hi rend="ital">painful</hi>, <hi rend="ital">unwelcome.</hi>—In the <hi rend="ital">neutr. subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcer-bum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <hi rend="ital">calamity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">misfortune</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:5:2:21" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 5, 2, 21</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:500" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 12, 500</bibl>—acerba, <gen>n.</gen> <hi rend="ital">plur. adv.</hi> acc. to the Gr. idiom, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 34</bibl> (cf. acuta et al.), several times imitated by <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:12:398" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 12, 398</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">9, 794</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:3:149" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> G. 3, 149</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcerbe</orth>, <hi rend="ital">harshly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sharply</hi>, <hi rend="ital">severely</hi>, etc., in the trop. signif. of the adj., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 1, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:33" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 2, 33</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:chapter=1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Planc. 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">idem acerbe severus in filium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:31:112" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3, 31, 112</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 50</bibl>. 12; 7, 3, 9; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:2:87 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 2, 87 al.</bibl>—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,052:chapter=16" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Lael. 16</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=tib.:25" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Tib. 25</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:11:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 11, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:1:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 1, 2</bibl>; also <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:35:86" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Planc. 35, 86</bibl>, where, of an exclamation of severe grief, acerbissime for acerrime is defended against Lambinus and Ernesti by Wunder, Planc. l. c. p. 217; so B. & K.</sense></entryFree>
acerneus: <entryFree id="n442" type="main" key="a^cerne^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcernĕus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>1. ăcer</etym>, <sense id="n442.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of maple</hi> (late Lat.): cancelli, Inscr. ap. Fabr. p. 745, note 513: pocula, Ven. Ep. 1 ad Greg. Pap.; cf. acernus.</sense></entryFree>
acernia: <entryFree id="n443" type="main" key="a^cerni^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcernĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n443.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an unknown fish</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cassiod.</author> Var. 2, 4</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acernus: <entryFree id="n444" type="main" key="a^cernus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcernus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>1. ăcer</etym>, <sense id="n444.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">made of</hi> <cb n="ACER" /> <hi rend="ital">maple</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">equus trabibus contextus acernis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:112" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 112</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">9, 87</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">solio,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 8, 178</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mensa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:8:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 8, 10</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:14:90" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 14, 90</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">mensae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Met. 12, 254 al.</bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
acerosus: <entryFree id="n445" type="main" key="a^ce^ro_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcĕrōsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>ăcus, ĕris</etym>, <sense id="n445.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">full of chaff</hi>: far, <hi rend="ital">mixed with chaff</hi>, Gr. <foreign lang="greek">au)to/puros</foreign>, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 445, 14</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">caenum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib.</bibl></cit>; v. Fest. s. v. OBACERARE, p. 187 Müll.</sense></entryFree>
acerra: <entryFree id="n446" type="main" key="a^cerra"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcerra</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>etym. unc., perh. from ăcer = maple</etym>, <sense id="n446.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a casket in which was kept the incense used in sacrifices</hi>, esp. in burning the dead, <hi rend="ital">an incense-box</hi>: ne sumptuosa respersio, ne longae coronae, nec acerrae praetereantur, from the XII. Tab. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,044:2:24:60" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Leg. 2, 24, 60</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">plenā veneratur larem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:745" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 745</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">plena turis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:8:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 8, 2</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">tacitā libabit acerrā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:2:5" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 2, 5</bibl></cit>; so also <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:13:703" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 13, 703</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Pont. 4, 8, 39</bibl>; Fratr. Arval. in Orell. I. L. 2270, p. 391 al. Cf. Fest. s. h. v. p. 18 Müll, who gives another signif.: “ACERRA, ara, quae ante mortuum poni solebat.”</sense></entryFree>
acerrae: <entryFree id="n447" type="main" key="A^cerrae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăcerrae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <sense id="n447.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A town in the interior of Campania</hi>, N. E. of Naples, now <hi rend="ital">Acerra</hi>, exposed to frequent inundations from the Clanius, on which it is situated; hence in Verg.: vacuis Clanius non aequus Acerris, G. 2, 225 Wagner; imitated by Silius, 8, 538.—Deriv., </sense><sense id="n447.1" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăcerrāni</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of A.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:27:3:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 27, 3, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:1:14:4" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 1, 14, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 5, 9, § 63</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n447.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A town in Umbria</hi>, called, for the sake of distinction, Acerrae Vatriae, now <hi rend="ital">Gerrha</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:114" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 14, 19, § 114</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acersecomes: <entryFree id="n448" type="greek" key="a^cerse^co^me_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcersĕcŏmēs</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)kerseko/mhs</foreign>, <sense id="n448.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">with unshorn hair;</hi> in Juv., <hi rend="ital">a young man</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a youth</hi>, 8, 128.</sense></entryFree>
acerus: <entryFree id="n449" type="greek" key="a^ce_rus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcērus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/khros</foreign>, <sense id="n449.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">without wax</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">mel acerum,</quote> <trans><tr>which flows spontaneously from the comb</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 15, 15, § 38</bibl></cit> lec. dub.</sense></entryFree>
acervalis: <entryFree id="n450" type="hapax" key="a^cerva_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcervālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>acervus</etym>, <sense id="n450.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that is heaped up</hi>, used by Cic. in dialec. lang. for the Gr. <foreign lang="greek">swrei/ths</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">a sophism by accumulation</hi>, Div. 2, 4, 11.</sense></entryFree>
acervatim: <entryFree id="n451" type="main" key="a^cerva_tim"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcervātim</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>, <sense id="n451.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">by heaping up</hi> or <hi rend="ital">accumulation</hi>, <hi rend="ital">by</hi> or <hi rend="ital">in heaps.</hi> </sense><sense id="n451.1" n="I" level="1"> Prop.: <cit><quote lang="la">confertos ita acervatim mors accumulabat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:1263" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 1263</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">stercus aspergi oportere in agro, non acervatim poni,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:38:1" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 38, 1</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:9:13:4" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 9, 13, 4</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">acervatim se de vallo praecipitaverunt,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Caes.</author> B. A. 31</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cadere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,033:18:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Sap. 18, 23</bibl></cit>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">pulmentis acervatim, panibus aggeratim, poculis agminatim ingestis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> M. 4, p. 146</bibl></cit> Elm.—</sense><sense id="n451.2" n="II" level="1"> Fig.: i. q. summatim, <hi rend="ital">crowded together</hi>, <hi rend="ital">briefly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">summarily</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">acervatim reliqua dicam, Cic, Clu. 10: multa acervatim frequentans,</quote> <trans><tr>crowding together many thoughts in one period</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Or. 25, 85</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 12, 23, § 69</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">hactenus populus Romanus cum singulis gentibus, mox acervatim,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:1:17:1" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 1, 17, 1</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
acervatio: <entryFree id="n452" type="hapax" key="a^cerva_ti^o"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcervātĭo</orth>, <itype>ōnis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>acervo</etym>, <sense id="n452.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a heaping up</hi>, <hi rend="ital">accumulation</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">saporum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:53:117" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 53, 117</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
acervo: <entryFree id="n453" type="main" key="a^cervo"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcervo</orth>, <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>acervus</etym>, <sense id="n453.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to form a heap</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to heap</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pile up</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to amass</hi> (rare, not in Cic.; per. not before the Aug. period). </sense><sense id="n453.1" n="I" level="1"> Prop.: <cit><quote lang="la">jam pigritiā singulos sepeliendi promiscue acervatos cumulos hominum urebant,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:5:48:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 5, 48, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aggerem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Here. Fur. 1216" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Here. Fur. 1216</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">panicum praedensis acervatur granis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:7:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 18, 7, 10</bibl></cit>: acervantur muricum modo, <hi rend="ital">they gather</hi> or <hi rend="ital">collect together</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:32:9:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 32, 9, 31</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n453.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to accumulate</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to multiply</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">leges,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 3, 34</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:3:47" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 9, 3, 47</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:26:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 26, 4, 10, § 21</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:101 al" default="NO" valid="yes">36, 15, 24, § 101 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
acervus: <entryFree id="n454" type="main" key="a^cervus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcervus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>v. 2. acer</etym>, <sense id="n454.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a multitude of objects of the same kind</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rising in a heap.</hi> </sense><sense id="n454.1" n="I" level="1"> Prop. </sense><sense id="n454.2" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A heap</hi> considered as a body: <cit><quote lang="la">frumenti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:1:2:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 1, 2, 55</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:1:1:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cas. 1, 1, 38</bibl>; Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 192, 3</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">altus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:198" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 198</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:775" default="NO" valid="yes">1, 775</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ut acervus ex sui generis granis, sic beata vita ex sui similibus partibus effici debeat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:15" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 5, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">acervi corporum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:3:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 3, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">pecuniae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:2:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Agr. 2, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tritici,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ac. 2, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">farris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:185" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 185</bibl></cit>; thus Ovid calls Chaos: caecus acervus, M. 1, 24.—</sense><sense id="n454.3" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A heap</hi> considered as a multitude (cf. Germ. <hi rend="ital">Haufen</hi> and Eng. colloq. <hi rend="ital">heap</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">aeris et auri,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 2, 47</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n454.4" n="II" level="1"> Fig. </sense><sense id="n454.5" n="A" level="2"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">a multitude</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">facinorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,015:chapter=27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Sull. 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">officiorum negotiorumque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:36:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 36, 5, 4, § 27</bibl></cit>: praeceptorum, Ov. <cb n="ACHA" /> Rem. Am. 424 al.—</sense><sense id="n454.6" n="B" level="2"> Esp., in dialectics, t. t., <hi rend="ital">a sophism formed by accumulation</hi>, Gr. <foreign lang="greek">swrei/ths</foreign>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Ac. 2, 16, 49</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 1, 47</bibl>; cf. acervalis.</sense></entryFree>
acesco: <entryFree id="n455" type="main" key="a^cesco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcesco</orth>, <itype>acui, 3</itype>, <sense id="n455.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">v. inch.</hi> [aceo], <hi rend="ital">to become sour</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to turn sour</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quodcumque infundis acescit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 2, 54</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">lac,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:14:53" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 20, 14, 53</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">musta,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:7:15:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 7, 15, 13</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 11, 16, 15, § 45</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:35:41" default="NO" valid="yes">11, 35, 41</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:18:1:9:section=2 al" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 18, 1, 9, § 2 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
acesines: <entryFree id="n456" type="main" key="A^ce^si^ne_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăcĕsĭnēs</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)akesi/nhs</foreign>, <sense id="n456.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river in India</hi>, <hi rend="ital">which falls into the Indus</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">the Chenaub</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:9:3:20" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 9, 3, 20</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:3:7:6" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 3, 7, 6</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:20:23 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 20, 23 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
acesinus: <entryFree id="n457" type="main" key="A^ce^si_nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăcĕsīnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n457.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to the river Acesinus in the Tauric Peninsula</hi> (<hi rend="ital">Crimea</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">agmina,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:6:69" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 6, 69</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
acesis: <entryFree id="n458" type="greek" key="a^ce^sis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcĕsis</orth>, is <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/kesis</foreign>, <sense id="n458.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a sort of borax</hi>, used in medicine, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:33:92" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 33, 5, 28, § 92</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acesta: <entryFree id="n459" type="main" key="A^cesta"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăcesta</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, also <orth extent="full" lang="la">Acestē</orth>, <itype>es</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)/akesta</foreign> and <foreign lang="greek">*)ake/sth</foreign>, <sense id="n459.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town in the N. W. part of Sicily</hi>, <hi rend="ital">near the coast;</hi> earlier Egesta, later Segesta, <hi rend="ital">near the modern Alcamo</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:718" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 718</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">9, 218</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad 1, 550</bibl>, and Heyne Excurs. I. ad Aen. V.—</sense><sense id="n459.1" n="II" level="1"> Deriv. </sense><sense id="n459.2" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăcestenses</orth>, <itype>ium</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">the inhabitants of A.</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:36:section=83" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 36, § 83</bibl>. —</sense><sense id="n459.3" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăcestaei</orth>, <hi rend="ital">the same</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:91" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 8, 14, § 91</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acestes: <entryFree id="n460" type="main" key="A^ceste_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăcestēs</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n460.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a mythical king of Sicily</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:757" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 757</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:83" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 83</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acetabulum: <entryFree id="n461" type="main" key="a^ce_ta_bu^lum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcētābŭlum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>acetum</etym>, orig., <sense id="n461.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a vessel for vinegar</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> 20</bibl> Orig. 4, 12; but in gen., </sense><sense id="n461.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Any cup-shaped vessel</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:8:6:35" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 8, 6, 35</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Ex. 25, 29</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">acetabula argen tea,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,004:7:84" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Num. 7, 84</bibl></cit>; as a liquid or dry measure, <hi rend="ital">the fourth part of a</hi> hemina, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0022,001:102" default="NO"><author>Cato</author> R. R. 102</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:7:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 18, 7, 14</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:21:34:109" default="NO" valid="yes">21, 34, 109</bibl>; and with jugglers, <hi rend="ital">the cup</hi> or <hi rend="ital">goblet</hi> with which they performed their feats, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 45:7" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 45, 7</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n461.2" n="II" level="1"> In anatomy, <hi rend="ital">the socket of the hip-bone</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:28:179" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 28, 11, 49, § 179</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n461.3" n="III" level="1"> In zoölogy, <hi rend="ital">the suckers</hi> or <hi rend="ital">cavities in the arms of polypi</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:9:29:46" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 9, 29, 46</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:30:48" default="NO" valid="yes">30, 48</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n461.4" n="IV" level="1"> In botany, <hi rend="ital">the cup of flowers</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:245" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 18, 26, 65, § 245</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acetaria: <entryFree id="n462" type="main" key="a^ce_ta_ri^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcētārĭa</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, sc. olera, <sense id="n462.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">that which is prepared with vinegar</hi> and oil, <hi rend="ital">salad</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:19:58" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 19, 4, 19, § 58</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:20:212" default="NO" valid="yes">20, 20, 81, § 212</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acetasco: <entryFree id="n463" type="main" key="a^ce_tasco"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcētasco</orth>, <itype>tāvi, 3</itype>, = acesco [id.], <sense id="n463.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to become sour</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 3</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
aceto: <entryFree id="n464" type="gloss" key="ace^to"><orth extent="full" lang="la">acĕto</orth>, <itype>āre, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos>, old form for agito, acc. to Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=23" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 23</bibl> Müll.; cf. the letter C.</entryFree>
acetum: <entryFree id="n465" type="main" key="a^ce_tum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcētum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>orig. <pos>P. a.</pos> fr. aceo, become sour, hence sc. vinum</etym>, <sense id="n465.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">sour wine</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wine-vinegar</hi>, or simply <hi rend="ital">vinegar</hi> (acc. to <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 9:section=66" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 9, § 66</bibl> Müll., only in the <number>sing.</number>). </sense><sense id="n465.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum aceto pransurus est et sale,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,017:4:2:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Rud. 4, 2, 32</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Verg.</author> M. 113</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">acre,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:2:3:117" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 2, 3, 117</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vetus,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>spoiled</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 2, 62</bibl></cit>: <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:21:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 21, 37</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:2:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cels.</author> 2, 18</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0836,001:2:21" default="NO" valid="yes">2, 21</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,004:19:29 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Joan. 19, 29 al.</bibl>: mulsum aceti, <hi rend="ital">vinegarmead</hi>, v. mulsus.—</sense><sense id="n465.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, of acuteness of mind, <hi rend="ital">sense</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wit</hi>, <hi rend="ital">shrewdness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sagacity</hi> (like <hi rend="ital">sal</hi>, <hi rend="ital">sales</hi>, wit, witty sayings, witticisms, fr. <hi rend="ital">sal</hi>, salt): <hi rend="ital">Ps.</hi> Ecquid habet is homo aceti in pectore? <hi rend="ital">Char.</hi> Atque acidissumi, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:2:4:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ps. 2, 4, 49</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:3:3:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Bacch. 3, 3, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:7:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 7, 32</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:5:86 al" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 5, 86 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
achaemenes: <entryFree id="n466" type="main" key="A^chaeme^ne_s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchaemĕnēs</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)axaime/nhs</foreign>, <sense id="n466.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the ancestor of the old Persian kings</hi>, <hi rend="ital">grandfather of Cyrus</hi>: dives Achaemenes, <usg type="style">poet.</usg> for <hi rend="ital">great</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Asiatic wealth</hi> in gen., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:2:12:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 2, 12, 21</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
achaemenides: <entryFree id="n467" type="main" key="A^chaeme^ni^des"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchaemĕnĭdes</orth> (Ache), <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n467.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a companion of Ulysses</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:614" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 614</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:161" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 161</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
achaemenis: <entryFree id="n468" type="greek" key="a^chaeme^nis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăchaemĕnis</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)xaimeni/s</foreign>, <sense id="n468.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an amber-colored plant in India</hi>, <hi rend="ital">used in magical arts</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:24:17:102" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 24, 17, 102</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:26:4:9" default="NO" valid="yes">26, 4, 9</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>App.</author> Herb. 56</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
achaemenius: <entryFree id="n469" type="main" key="A^chaeme^ni^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchaemĕnĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>Achaemenes q. v.</etym>, <sense id="n469.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Persian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">urbes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:4:212" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 4, 212</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">costum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:1:44 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 1, 44 al.</bibl></cit></sense></entryFree>
achaetus: <entryFree id="n470" type="main" key="A^chaetus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchaetus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n470.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river of Sicily</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:14:268" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 14, 268</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
achaeus: <entryFree id="n471" type="main" key="A^chaeus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchaeus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <sense id="n471.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Son of Xuthus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">brother of Ion</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and ancestor of the Achaei.</hi> —</sense><sense id="n471.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A king of Lydia</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:301" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Ib. 301</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n472" type="main" key="A^chaeus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchaeus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)axaio/s</foreign>. <sense id="n472.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Belonging to Achaia; subst.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an Achaean</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Achaeis in finibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:1114" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 1114</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:35:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 35, 13</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n472.1" n="B" level="2"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">Grecian; subst.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a Greek</hi> (v. Achaia, II.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:3:61" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 3, 61</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:2:164" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 2, 164</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:7:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 7, 14</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n472.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An inhabitant of a Greek colony on the Black Sea</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Pont. 4, 10, 27</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n472.3" n="III" level="1"> Portus Achaeorum, <hi rend="ital">the harbor<pb n="22" /> <cb n="ACHE" />  before Troy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">where the Greeks landed</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:12:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 12, 26</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
achaia: <entryFree id="n473" type="main" key="A^cha_ia"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchāia</orth> <itype>or</itype> (in poets) <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchāĭa</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">quadrisyl.</orth>), <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym><foreign lang="greek">*)axai/a</foreign></etym>. <sense id="n473.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The province of Achaia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in the northern part of the Peloponnesus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">on the Gulf of Corinth</hi>, earlier called Aegialea (maritime country), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:3:4" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 3, 4</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:5:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 5, 6</bibl>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n473.1" n="B" level="2"> In gen. (cf. the Homeric <foreign lang="greek">*)axaioi/</foreign>), for <hi rend="ital">Greece</hi>, opposite to Troja: <cit><quote lang="la">et quot Troja tulit, vetus et quot Achaia formas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:2:21:53" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 2, 21, 53</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:268" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 268</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Her. 17, 209 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n473.2" n="II" level="1"> After the destruction of Corinth by Mummius, B. C. 146, Greece proper became a Rom. prov. under the name of <hi rend="ital">Achaia.</hi>— Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchāĭăs</orth>, <itype>ădis</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">An Achaean</hi> or <hi rend="ital">Greek woman</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:3:71" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 3, 71</bibl>.—<orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchāĭ-cus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">Achaean</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Grecian.</hi> </sense><sense id="n473.3" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, opp. to Trojan: <cit><quote lang="la">manus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:623" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 623</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ignis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:15:35" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 15, 35</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n473.4" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Belonging to the Roman province Achaia</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">homines,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:1:13:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 1, 13, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">negotium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:4:4:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Fam. 4, 4, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">concilium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:43:17:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 43, 17, 4</bibl></cit>.—Hence L. Mummius obtained, for the destruction of Corinth and the complete subjugation of Greece, the honorary title of <hi rend="ital">Achaïcus.</hi> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:1:13:2" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 1, 13, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:35:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 35, 4, 8, § 24</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">and so as surname of one of his descendants: Mummia Achaica,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=gal.:3" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Galb. 3</bibl></cit>.—<orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchāĭs</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <gen>f.</gen> </sense><sense id="n473.5" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Achaean</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Grecian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">urbes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:5:306" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 5, 306</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n473.6" n="II" level="1"> <pos>Subst.</pos>, = Achaia, <hi rend="ital">Achaia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Greece</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:5:577" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 5, 577</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">7, 504</bibl>.— <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchāĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">adj.: Achaean</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Grecian</hi> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg> for Achaïcus and Achaeus): <cit><quote lang="la">castra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:462" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 462</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:14:5" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 14, 5</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:15:306" default="NO">15, 306</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
achantum: <entryFree id="n474" type="main" key="a^chantum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăchantum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <sense id="n474.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kind of frankincense</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Veg.</author> 1, 20</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
achanum: <entryFree id="n475" type="main" key="a^cha^num"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăchănum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym><foreign lang="greek">a)xanh/s</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">mute</hi>, <hi rend="ital">stupid</hi>, Gesner</etym>, <sense id="n475.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a disease of animals</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Veg.</author> 3, 2</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acharnae: <entryFree id="n476" type="main" key="A^charnae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăcharnae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n476.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a demus</hi> or <hi rend="ital">borough of Attica</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:12:623" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 12, 623</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăcharnānus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">of Acharnae</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,002:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Them. 1</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acharne: <entryFree id="n477" type="main" key="a^charne_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăcharnē</orth>, <itype>ēs</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n477.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a sea-fish</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 32</bibl>. 11, 53, § 145. (Al. acarne.)</sense></entryFree>
acharrae: <entryFree id="n478" type="main" key="A^charrae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăcharrae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n478.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town of Thessaly</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:32:13:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 32, 13, 13</bibl>.</sense><sense id="n478.1" n="1" level="3"> † <orth extent="full" lang="la">ăchātēs</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> and <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">o( a)xa/ths</foreign>, <hi rend="ital">the agate</hi>, so called from Achates, a river in Sicily, where it was first found, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:37:10:55" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 37, 10, 55</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:14:228" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 14, 228</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
achates: <entryFree id="n479" type="main" key="A^cha_tes1" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchātes</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n479.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a river in the southern part of Sicily</hi>, <hi rend="ital">between Thermae and Selinus</hi>, now unknown, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:90" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 8, 14, § 90</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n480" type="main" key="A^cha_tes2" n="3"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchātes</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n480.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the armor-bearer and faithful friend of Aeneas</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:120" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 120</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">174</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Fast. 3, 603 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
acheloias: <entryFree id="n481" type="main" key="A^che^lo_i^a^s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchĕlōĭăs</orth>, <itype>ădis</itype>, <sense id="n481.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">patron. f.</hi> [Achelous], <hi rend="ital">daughter of Achelous;</hi> hence (plur.), <hi rend="ital">the Sirens</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:87" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 87</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Parthenope,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:12:34" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 12, 34</bibl></cit>; cf. the follg. art.</sense></entryFree>
achelois: <entryFree id="n482" type="main" key="A^che^lo_i^s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchĕlōĭs</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <sense id="n482.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">patron. f.</hi> [id.], <hi rend="ital">daughter of Achelous;</hi> hence (plur.), <hi rend="ital">the Sirens</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:5:552" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 5, 552</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acheloius: <entryFree id="n483" type="main" key="A^che^lo_i^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchĕlōĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>. <sense id="n483.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Pertaining to the river Achelous</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,002:16:265" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> H. 16, 265</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Callirrhoë,</quote> <trans><tr>daughter of Achelous</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:9:413" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> M. 9, 413</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n483.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Aetolian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">heros,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>Tydeus</tr>, <tr>the son of Oeneus</tr>, <tr>king of Aetolia</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,001:2:142" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> Th. 2, 142</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
achelous: <entryFree id="n484" type="main" key="A^che^lo_u^s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchĕlōŭs</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <foreign lang="greek">*)axelw=os</foreign>. <sense id="n484.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A celebrated river of Middle Greece</hi>, <hi rend="ital">which</hi>, <hi rend="ital">rising in Pindus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">separates Aetolia from Acarnania</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and empties into the Ionian Sea</hi>, now the <hi rend="ital">Aspropotamo</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:2:3:10" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 2, 3, 10</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:1:2 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 1, 2 al.</bibl>—Hence, </sense><sense id="n484.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The river-god Achelous</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:8:549 sq" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 8, 549 sq.</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">10, 8</bibl> sq.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:2:34:33 al" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 2, 34, 33 al.</bibl></sense></entryFree>
achemenides: <entryFree id="n485" type="main" key="A^che_me^ni^des"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchēmĕnĭdes</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, v. Achaem.</entryFree>
acherini: <entryFree id="n486" type="main" key="A^che^ri_ni"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchĕrīni</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n486.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an unknown people in Sicily</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:3:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 3, 43</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acheron: <entryFree id="n487" type="main" key="A^che^ron"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchĕron</orth>, <itype>ntis</itype> (collat. form Acheros, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:24:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 24, 11</bibl>; the form Acheruns, untis, see below), <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)axe/rwn</foreign> (interpr. <foreign lang="greek">o( a)/xea r(e/wn</foreign>, <sense id="n487.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the stream of woe</hi>). </sense><sense id="n487.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A river in Epirus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">which flows through the Lake Acherusia into the Ambracian Gulf</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Suli</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:24:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 24, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 1, 1, § 4</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n487.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A fabulous river in the Lower World</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">illi qui fluere apud inferos dicuntur, Acheron, Cocytus, Styx, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:17" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 17</bibl></cit>: via Tartarei quae fert Acherontis ad undas, Verg. A., 6, 295 al.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n487.3" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">The Lower World itself</hi>: Acherontem obibo, ubi mortis<cb n="ACHI" />  thesauri objacent, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=201" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 201</bibl> Müll. (Trag. v. 278 ed. Vahl.): <cit><quote lang="la">flectere si nequeo Superos, Acheronta movebo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:312" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 312</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">perrupit Acheronta Herculeus labor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:3:36" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 3, 36</bibl></cit>. In prose: <cit><quote lang="la">ut eum suo sanguine ab Acheronte, si possent, cuperent redimere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0588,001:Dion. 10:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Nep.</author> Dion. 10, 2</bibl></cit>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchĕrontēus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">pertaining to the Acheron</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> Rapt. Pros. 2, 351</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acherontia: <entryFree id="n488" type="main" key="A^che^ronti^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchĕrontĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n488.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a small town of Apulia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">near the frontiers of Lucania</hi>, <hi rend="ital">situated on a hill</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Acerenza</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">celsa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:4:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 4, 14</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
acheronticus: <entryFree id="n489" type="main" key="A^che^ronti^cus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchĕrontĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <sense id="n489.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">belonging to the Acheron</hi> or <hi rend="ital">the Lower World</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">stagna,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Prud.</author> Cath. 5, 127</bibl></cit>: libri, <hi rend="ital">sacred books</hi>, <hi rend="ital">written</hi>, <hi rend="ital">according to tradition</hi>, <hi rend="ital">by the Etruscan Tages</hi>, prob. relating to the Acherontian rites of the dead, <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> adv. Gent. 2, p. 87</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Aen. 8, 398</bibl>; and Müll. Etrusc. 1, p. 77.</sense></entryFree>
acheros: <entryFree id="n490" type="main" key="A^che^ros"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchĕros</orth>, v. Acheron <sense id="n490.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">init.</hi></sense></entryFree>
acheruns: <entryFree id="n491" type="main" key="A^che^runs"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchĕruns</orth>, <itype>untis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>v. Acheron</etym> (<gen>f.</gen>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:5:4:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 5, 4, 2</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> 191, 24</bibl>; <usg type="style">poet.</usg> in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:16:37" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 16, 37</bibl>; the u for o, as in Enn. and Lucr. <sense id="n491.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">frundes</hi> for frondes, <case>acc.</case> Gr. Acherunta, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:170" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 4, 170</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:251" default="NO" valid="yes">6, 251</bibl>); a form much used by ante-class. poets, esp. by Plaut., </sense><sense id="n491.1" n="I" level="1"> For Acheron <hi rend="ital">no.</hi> II. B.: adsum atque advenio Acherunte, <usg type="style">poet.</usg> ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:16:37" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 16, 37</bibl>; R<bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> Trag. Rel. p. 245</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">si ab Acherunte veniam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:5:1:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Am. 5, 1, 26</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:37" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 37</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:628 al" default="NO" valid="yes">628 al.</bibl>—And with the ending <hi rend="ital">i</hi> (as in Karthagini): <cit><quote lang="la">si neque hic neque Acherunti sum, ubi sum?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:3:4:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Merc. 3, 4, 21</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:3:5:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Capt. 3, 5, 31</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5, 4, 1</bibl>. —Acheruntis pabulum, <hi rend="ital">food for Acheron;</hi> said of a corrupt, abandoned man, in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:2:1:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Cas. 2, 1, 12</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Acheruntis ostium, disparagingly of bad land,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,019:2:4:124" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Trin. 2, 4, 124</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">mittere aliquem Acheruntem,</quote> <trans><tr>to kill one</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,006:2:8:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cas. 2, 8, 12</bibl></cit>; and: <cit><quote lang="la">abire ad Acheruntem,</quote> <trans><tr>to die</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,015:prol. 71" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Poen. prol. 71</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ulmorum Acheruns, jestingly of a slave, upon whose back rods had been broken,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,001:4:2:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Am. 4, 2, 9</bibl></cit> (cf. Capt. 3, 4, 117).—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchĕruntĭcus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">belonging to</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">fit for</hi>, <hi rend="ital">Acheruns</hi>, or <hi rend="ital">the Lower World</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">regiones,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:2:2:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 2, 2, 21</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">senex,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>with one foot in the grave</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:2:2:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Merc. 2, 2, 19</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,012:3:1:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Mil. 3, 1, 33</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acherusia: <entryFree id="n492" type="main" key="A^che^ru_si^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchĕrūsĭa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>Acheruns</etym>. <sense id="n492.0" n="I" level="1"> Acherusia Palus, </sense><sense id="n492.1" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A lake in Epirus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">through which the Acheron flows</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:4:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 4, 1, 1</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n492.2" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">A lake in Campania</hi>, <hi rend="ital">between Misenum and Cumae</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Lago di Fusaro</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:5:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 3, 5, 9</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n492.3" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A cave in Bithynia</hi>, <hi rend="ital">from which Cerberus is said to have been dragged</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0929,001:1:19:7" default="NO"><author>Mel.</author> 1, 19, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:6:1:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 6, 1, 1</bibl>; the same called <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchĕrūsĭs</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:5:73" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 5, 73</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
acherusius: <entryFree id="n493" type="main" key="A^che^ru_si^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchĕrūsĭus</orth> (old writing Acherunsius), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>id.</etym>. <sense id="n493.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Pertaining to the Acheron in Calabria</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">aqua,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:24" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 24</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n493.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Pertaining to the Acheruns</hi> (Acheron), or <hi rend="ital">the Lower World</hi>: templa, <hi rend="ital">the Lower World</hi>, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:1:21:48" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 1, 21, 48</bibl> (Trag. v. 107 ed. Vahl.); in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 7:section=6" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 7, § 6</bibl> Müll.; and in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:120" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 120</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 25</bibl> and 86: <cit><quote lang="la">humor,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:13:398" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 13, 398</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vita,</quote> <trans><tr>a life of gloom</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:1024" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 1024</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n493.2" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Pertaining to Acheron in Epirus</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">amnis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:12:2:3" default="NO"><author>Just.</author> 12, 2, 3</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
acheta: <entryFree id="n494" type="greek" key="a_che^ta"><orth extent="full" lang="la">āchĕta</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)xe/ths, h)xe/ths</foreign> (sounding; <sense id="n494.0" n="I" level="1"><cit><quote lang="la">pr. the chirper),</quote> <trans><tr>the male singing cicada</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:92" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 26, 32, § 92</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
achilla: <entryFree id="n495" type="main" key="A^chilla"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchilla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, v. Acholla.</entryFree>
achillas: <entryFree id="n496" type="main" key="A^chillas"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchillas</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n496.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the murderer of Pompey</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,002:3:104" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. C. 3, 104</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">108</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:8:538" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 8, 538</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
achillea: <entryFree id="n497" type="main" key="a^chille_a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăchillēa</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, <sense id="n497.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a plant</hi>, perhaps the same as <hi rend="ital">achilleos</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:26:15:90" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 26, 15, 90</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
achilleides: <entryFree id="n498" type="main" key="A^chille^i^des"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchillĕĭdes</orth>, v. Achillides.</entryFree>
achilleis: <entryFree id="n499" type="main" key="A^chille_i^s"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchillēĭs</orth>, <itype>ĭdis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>Achilles</etym>, <sense id="n499.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a poem of Statius</hi>, of which only two books were finished, <hi rend="ital">the Achilleid.</hi></sense></entryFree>
achilleos: <entryFree id="n500" type="main" key="a^chille_os"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăchillēos</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)axi/lleios</foreign>, sc. herba, <sense id="n500.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a medicinal plant</hi>, <hi rend="ital">said to have been discovered by Achilles</hi>, <hi rend="ital">milfoil</hi> or <hi rend="ital">yarrow</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:25:5:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 25, 5, 19</bibl>; cf. achillea.</sense></entryFree>
achilles: <entryFree id="n501" type="main" key="A^chilles"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ăchilles</orth>, <itype>is</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)axilleu/s</foreign> (<usg type="style">poet.</usg>, after the manner of the Gr. <sense id="n501.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">Nom.</hi>, Achilleus, trisyl., <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Grut.</author> 669, 6</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Gen.</hi> Achillei, quadrisyl., <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:15:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 15, 34</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:17:14" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Epod. 17, 14</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">and Achilli, as Neocli, Lacydi from Neocles, Lacydes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:4:9:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 4, 9, 14</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:3:87" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 3, 87</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0996,001:1468" default="NO"><author>Val. Prob.</author> 1468</bibl> P.—<hi rend="ital">Acc.</hi> Achillĕa, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:10:523" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 10, 523</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Voc.</hi> Achille, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:4:11:40" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 4, 11, 40</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Abl.</hi> Achilli, <bibl default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Pont. 3, 3, 43</bibl>), <hi rend="ital">the celebrated Grecian hero in the Trojan</hi> <cb n="ACIE" /> <hi rend="ital">war</hi>, <hi rend="ital">distinguished for strength and beauty</hi>; <hi rend="ital">son of Peleus</hi>, <hi rend="ital">king of Thessaly</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and of Thetis</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 12 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl> and 13 <hi rend="ital">init.</hi>; Stat. Achill. al. In the fine arts, Achilles is represented with hair long and erect, like a mane, a body straight and slender, nostrils (<foreign lang="greek">mukth=res</foreign>) distended with courage and pride, and a physical frame throughout noble and powerful, Müll.
